title: State v. Paige
description: In this criminal matter, the appellant appeals his conviction for involuntary manslaughter asserting the trial judge erred in failing to require spectators in the courtroom to remove photograph buttons of the deceased from their clothing.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Donald Wayne
      Paige, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Greenville County
Â G. Edward Welmaker, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4320
Submitted November 1, 2007 â€“ Filed
  December 4, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Deputy
  Chief Attorney for Capital Appeals Robert M. Dudek, of the South Carolina
  Commission on Indigent Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				
				Attorney
  General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh,
  Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney
  General Norman Mark Rapoport, of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of
  Greenville, for Respondent.
			
		
	


HUFF,
  J.:Â  Appellant, Donald Wayne Paige,
  was indicted for murder and subsequently convicted of involuntary manslaughter.[1]Â 
  He appeals, asserting the trial judge erred in failing to require spectators at
  his trial to remove photograph buttons of the deceased from their clothing.Â  We
  affirm.[2]
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
This
  case arose from a tragic confrontation involving three men, resulting in the
  shotgun death of one of them.Â  The evidence presented at trial shows that
  around 9:00 in the morning on April 23, 2004, Donald Paige and his friend and
  employer, Ray Davis, arrived at the camper home of the victim, Jason Henderson,
  and his fiancÃ©e, Andrea Pruitt.Â  Paige and Davis knocked on the door, and Henderson answered it.Â  Paige held a sawed-off shotgun.Â  A conversation ensued and heated
  words were exchanged between Henderson and Paige.Â  Although there is some
  dispute as to whether Paige pointed the gun at Henderson and whether Henderson
  grabbed the gun, causing it to discharge, it is undisputed that the gun went
  off, hitting Henderson in his abdomen, resulting in his death.Â  It is also
  undisputed that Paige entered Hendersonâ€™s property accompanied by Davis for the purpose of confronting Henderson about a
  financial dispute between Henderson and Davis, he did so armed with a sawed-off
  shotgun, and when he knocked on Hendersonâ€™s door he had the shotgun loaded and
  cocked with his finger on the trigger.Â   
LAW/ANALYSIS
The only issue raised on appeal is whether the trial court
  erred in denying appellantâ€™s motion to have spectators in the courtroom remove
  from their clothing photograph buttons of the victim.Â  Appellant contends there
  was evidence the decedent was â€œgoing after appellant when the gun accidentallyâ€
  discharged, and that, by wearing the buttons, the spectators were attempting to
  create sympathy â€œfor what otherwise did not appear to be a very sympathetic
  situation,â€ to the prejudice of appellant.Â  Appellant maintains he is thus
  entitled to a new trial.Â  We disagree.
The
  record reveals that prior to jury selection in Paigeâ€™s trial, defense counsel
  indicated she had a matter to bring to the courtâ€™s attention.Â  Counsel noted
  that there were â€œseveral persons sitting on this side behind the State with
  pictures taped to their clothing.â€Â  She inquired whether they were pictures of
  the deceased and asked, if they were, that the spectators remove them.Â  The
  solicitor responded that they were pictures of the deceased, that his family
  members had the buttons created after his death, and that none of the Stateâ€™s
  witnesses would be wearing them.Â  The court questioned whether any of these
  individuals would be testifying, and the solicitor indicated they would not.Â 
  The following colloquy then occurred:

	[Court]:Â They
  will be sitting in the back of the courtroom?Â  None of them will be at the
  counsel table?
	[Solicitor]: None
  will be at the table, Your Honor.Â  We will be happy to put them in whatever row
  the court deems appropriate, but certainly they are - - itâ€™s a public courtroom
  and a photograph of the deceased canâ€™t be prejudicial.

Defense counsel objected,
  stating the purpose of the photo was to invoke jury sympathy for the Stateâ€™s
  case, and because they were sitting behind the State in the courtroom, it was
  prejudicial to the defendant. Â The court ruled it would not require the individuals
  to remove the buttons, but would make sure that they did not sit on the front
  row of seats.Â  He further instructed the solicitor that she was to instruct
  these spectators there were to be no gestures of any kind made by them, or they
  would be removed from the courtroom.Â  The court stated if they pointed to the
  picture or did anything to try to influence the jury, it would not be
  tolerated.Â  The solicitor insured the court these individuals would be
  instructed accordingly.Â  Thereafter, the jury was drawn and the trial
  proceeded, with no further mention of the buttons.
Whether
  a defendantâ€™s fair trial rights may be violated when spectators wear photo
  buttons of the victim at his or her trial is a matter of first impression in
  this jurisdiction.Â  The United States Supreme Court has recently indicated that
  the effect of spectators wearing such buttons on a defendantâ€™s fair trial
  rights was an open question.Â  Carey v. Musladin, ___U.S. ___, ___, 127
  S. Ct. 649, 653 (2006).Â  In Carey, the state court, citing Holbrook
    v. Flynn, 475 U.S. 560 (1986), found Musladin had to show actual or
  inherent prejudice to succeed on his claim, and concluded the buttons â€œhad not
  branded defendant with an unmistakable mark of guilt in the eyes of the
  jurors.â€Â  Id. at 652.Â  At the conclusion of the state appellate process,
  Musladin filed an application for writ of habeas corpus in federal district
  court, which the District Court denied.Â  The Court of Appeals for the Ninth
  Circuit reversed, finding the state courtâ€™s decision was contrary to, or
  involved an unreasonable application of, clearly established federal law.Â  Id.Â  In particular, the Court of Appeals relied on the Supreme Courtâ€™s decisions in Estelle
    v. Williams, 425 U.S. 501 (1976) and Holbrook v. Flynn, 475 U.S. 560
  (1986). Â Id.Â  The Supreme Court vacated, finding there was a lack of
  holdings from the court regarding the potentially prejudicial effect of
  spectator courtroom conduct and, thus, the state court did not unreasonably
  apply clearly established federal law.[3]Â  Id. at 654.Â  In doing so, the Supreme Court observed that both Williams,
  wherein the State compelled the defendant to stand trial in prison garb, and Flynn,
  wherein the State seated four uniformed troopers immediately behind the
  defendant at trial, involved government-sponsored courtroom practices, as
  opposed to the spectator conduct complained of by Musladin.Â  Id. Â at
  653.Â  While the court had articulated the test for inherent prejudice that
  applies to state conduct in Williams and Flynn, the court
  concluded it had never applied that test to spectatorsâ€™ conduct.Â  The court
  then pointed out, â€œIndeed, part of the legal test of Williams and Flynn â€“ asking whether the practices furthered an essential state interest â€“
  suggests that those cases apply only to state sponsored practices.â€ Â Id. at 653-54.
Turning
  to our own established law, we note the general rule in this State is that the
  conduct of a criminal trial is left largely to the sound discretion of the
  trial court, and the appellate court will not interfere unless it clearly
  appears that the rights of the complaining party were abused or prejudiced in
  some way.Â  State v. Bridges, 278 S.C. 447, 448, 298 S.E.2d 212, 212
  (1982).Â Â  As to courtroom conduct, our courts have held that a defendant in a
  criminal prosecution is constitutionally guaranteed a fair trial by an
  impartial jury, and in order to fully safeguard this protection, it is required
  that the jury render its verdict free from outside influence.Â  State v.
    Carrigan, 284 S.C. 610, 613-14, 328 S.E.2d 119, 121 (Ct. App. 1985).Â  In State
      v. Stewart, 278 S.C. 296, 295 S.E.2d 627 (1982), cert. denied, 459
  U.S. 828 (1982), our supreme court stated as follows:

	The
  right to a fair trial by an impartial jury in a criminal prosecution is
  guaranteed by the Sixth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution and by Article I, Â§
  14, of the S.C. Constitution.Â  While this right does not require a â€œperfectâ€
  trial, the very heart of a â€œfair trialâ€ embodies a disciplined courtroom
  wherein an accusedâ€™s fate is determined solely through the exercise of calm and
  informed judgment.
	
		Ideal
  conditions, it is true, are not to be expected, and verdicts should not be set
  aside by an appellate court for misconduct in a trial, unless the evidence is
  clear and convincing that extraneous influences so interfered with the conduct
  of the trial, or so pressed upon the jury, as to become factors in the result.Â  
		State v. Weldon, 91 S.C. 29, 74 S.E. 43 (1912).
	
	It is
  the duty of the trial judge to see that the integrity of his court is not
  obstructed by any person or persons whatsoever.Â  Shearer v. DeShon, 240
  S.C. 472, 126 S.E.2d 514 (1962); 75 Am.Jur.2d Trial Â§ 40 (1974).Â  His exercise
  of this duty will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion.

Id. at 303-04, 295 S.E.2d at 630-31.
While
  research reveals our state courts have not addressed the issue of spectator
  courtroom conduct of wearing buttons displaying photos of the victim, our
  supreme court has addressed the issue of the government-sponsored courtroom
  practice of having uniformed officers present in the courtroom. Â In State v.
    Hill, 331 S.C. 94, 501 S.E.2d 122 (1998), cert. denied, 525 U.S. 1043 (1998), Hill asserted the presence of the officers â€œwas a show of force which
  denied him a fair trial.â€Â  Id. at 100-01, 501 S.E.2d at 125-26.Â  Citing Holbrook
    v. Flynn, 475 U.S. 560 (1986), the court held that in order to prevail on
  such a claim, Hill was required to show that measures taken in the courtroom
  created either an actual or inherent prejudicial effect on the jury.Â  Id. at 101, 501 S.E.2d at 126.Â  â€œInherent prejudice occurs when â€˜an unacceptable
  risk is presented of impermissible factors coming into play.â€™â€Â  Id. citing Flynn. Â Noting the court could not determine from the record how
  many uniformed officers were present, nor whether they were present to provide
  security or to testify, it found any actual prejudice in the case was wholly
  speculative, and Hill failed to present any evidence to show the presence of
  the officers had any effect on the jury.Â  The court further determined that
  without anything more than Hillâ€™s mere assertion that six officers were present
  in the courtroom, the court could not find Hill had shown any inherent
  prejudice.Â  Id.
In
  the case at hand, assuming arguendo that our state courts would apply the
  â€œactual or inherent prejudicial effect on the juryâ€ test to this spectator, as
  opposed to state-sponsored conduct, we conclude Paige has failed to show any
  actual or inherent prejudice under the circumstances of this case.Â  The record
  shows the only mention of the buttons was prior to jury selection, and out of
  the presence of the jury venire, at which time defense counsel had to inquire
  whether the buttons did in fact depict a picture of the victim.Â  There is no
  evidence of the size of the buttons, or the number of spectators who wore the
  buttons.Â  While the trial court stated he would not require the individuals to
  remove the buttons, he insured that these spectators would not be called as
  witnesses, nor would they be seated in the front row.Â  He further instructed
  that these individuals would not be allowed to make gestures, point to the
  pictures, or do anything in an attempt to influence the jury.Â  Because no other
  mention was made of the buttons, this court cannot even determine that these
  spectators remained in the courtroom for the remainder of the trial or, if they
  did, whether they continued to wear the buttons.Â  Simply put, there is
  absolutely no evidence of record that the jurors in this matter were ever
  exposed to these button photos, and, if they were, whether they could perceive
  that they depicted the victim.Â  Accordingly, we find no actual or inherent
  prejudice to Paige based on the record before us.Â  Additionally, the evidence
  is not clear and convincing of extraneous influences that â€œso interfered with
  the conduct of the trial, or so pressed upon the jury,â€ as to become factors in
  the result of Paigeâ€™s trial.Â  State v. Stewart, 278 S.C. at 303, 295
  S.E.2d at 631 (quoting State v. Weldon, 91 S.C. 29, 74 S.E. 43 (1912)).Â  
 
Based on the foregoing, Paigeâ€™s conviction is
AFFIRMED.
PIEPER, JJ., and CURETON, AJ., concur.

[1] Paige was also indicted for and convicted of
  possession of a weapon during the commission of a violent crime.Â  However, the
  trial judge, with the Stateâ€™s consent, vacated the weapons charge based on a
  determination that involuntary manslaughter did not qualify as a crime of
  violence.
[2]We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.  
[3]The Supreme Court pointed out that the lack of
  guidance from its own court was reflected in the lower courtsâ€™ widely divergent
  treatment of defendantsâ€™ spectator-conduct claims, ranging from applying Williams and Flynn to spectator claims, to distinguishing Flynn on the
  facts, to ruling on the issue without relying on, discussing, or distinguishing Williams or Flynn.Â  Musladin, 127 S. Ct. at 654.Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â

title: State v. Serrette
description: Jerry Gerald Serrette appeals from his convictions for trafficking cocaine and possession with intent to distribute marijuana.  Serrette contends this court should remand for a reconstruction hearing because the record of his original trial was lost during the nearly eleven-year gap between conviction and sentencing due to his fugitive status.  We dismiss.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				Jerry Gerald
      Serrette, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Horry County
Â JohnÂ  L.Â  Breeden, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No.Â  4321
Submitted December 1, 2007 â€“ Filed
  December 4, 2007
APPEAL DISMISSED


	
		
			
				Deputy Chief Attorney for Capital Appeals Robert M. Dudek, South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott,
				Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., Office of
  the Attorney General, of Columbia; and Solicitor John Gregory Hembree, of Conway, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: Jerry
  Gerald Serrette appeals from his convictions for trafficking cocaine and
  possession with intent to distribute marijuana.Â  Serrette contends this court
  should remand for a reconstruction hearing because the record of his original
  trial was lost during the nearly eleven-year gap between conviction and
  sentencing due to his fugitive status.Â  We dismiss.
FACTS
On October 12, 1994, Serrette was convicted in absentia for trafficking cocaine and possession with intent to distribute marijuana.Â  A
  bench warrant was issued, and over ten years later, Serrette was arrested and
  sentenced to six yearsâ€™ imprisonment for the cocaine charge and a concurrent
  four yearsâ€™ imprisonment on the marijuana charge.Â  After filing a notice of
  appeal, Serrette learned his trial transcript had been destroyed pursuant to
  Rule 607(i), SCACR, which allows court reporters to reuse or destroy tapes of a
  proceeding after five years.Â  On appeal, Serrette asks this court to remand for
  a reconstruction hearing.Â  The State opposes a remand and contends the case
  should be dismissed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Serrette
  argues he is entitled to a direct appeal, which cannot be meaningfully
  perfected without a trial transcript.Â  He asks that we remand his case to have
  the record reconstructed and allow the circuit court to determine whether
  reconstruction is possible. The State counters that dismissing the appeal is an
  appropriate sanction because Serretteâ€™s willful decision to remain a fugitive
  from justice for nearly eleven years has â€œpresent[ed] an obstacle to orderly
  appellate reviewâ€ as discussed in Ortega-Rodriguez v. United States, 507
  U.S. 234, 251 (1993).Â  We agree with the Stateâ€™s position.
Though South Carolina affords criminal defendants the
  opportunity to appeal, the right to an appeal may be lost through a variety of
  actions by an appellant, such as: (1) failure to timely serve a notice of
  appeal under Rule 203, SCACR; (2) failure to serve and file an initial brief and
  designation of matter under Rule 208(a)(4), SCACR; or (3) failure to serve and
  file a record on appeal and final brief under Rules 210 and 211, SCACR.Â  See Rule 231, SCACR.Â  Furthermore, the burden is on the appellant to provide the
  appellate court with an adequate record for review.Â  State v. Williams,
  321 S.C. 455, 464 n.4, 469 S.E.2d 49, 54 n.4 (1996).Â   
In Ortega-Rodriguez
  v. United States, 507 U.S. 234 (1993), the United States Supreme Court
  found that a rule which automatically dismissed the appeal of a one time
  fugitive was not proper.Â  The Court found that the fact the appellant was a
  fugitive had to â€œhave an impact on the appellate process sufficient to warrant
  an appellate sanction.â€Â  Id. at 249.Â  In addition, the Court noted: â€œa
  long escape, even if ended before sentencing and appeal, may so delay the onset
  of appellate proceedings that the Government would be prejudiced . . . . We
  recognize that this problem might, in some instances, make dismissal an
  appropriate response.â€Â  Id.
Serrette
  points out that our court has the authority to remand for a reconstruction of
  the record pursuant to China v. Parrott, 251 S.C. 329, 162 S.E.2d 276
  (1968); however, such a remedy would undoubtedly be futile considering the
  passage of over ten yearsâ€™ time between conviction and sentencing.[1]Â Â  See State v. Ladson, 373 S.C. 320, 326, 644 S.E.2d 271, 274 (Ct.
  App. 2007) (â€œIt is simply unrealistic and unreasonable to think that a trial
  judge and counsel can â€“ under these circumstances [the passage of fourteen
  months] â€“ reconstruct a proper record that will permit meaningful appellate review,
  especially in light of our issue preservation rules.â€).Â  Furthermore,
  Serretteâ€™s own actions are the reason a transcript of the proceedings below is
  not available; this is not a situation where the court reporterâ€™s equipment
  malfunctioned at trial leading to a loss of the trial transcript.Â  See Deaton
    v. Leath, 279 S.C. 82, 84, 302 S.E.2d 335, 336 (1983).Â  We can divine no
  reason why Serrette is entitled to a reconstruction of the record when the destruction
  of the transcript resulted from his willful decision to remain a fugitive.Â 
 
Instead,
  we find Serretteâ€™s actions have â€œthe kind of connection to the appellate
  process that [justifies] an appellate sanction of dismissal.â€Â  Ortega-Rodriguez,
  507 U.S. at 251 (1993); see also State v. Verikokides, 925 P.2d
  1255, 1256 (Utah 1996) (holding that a criminal appeal may be dismissed if â€œthe
  State can show that it has been prejudiced by the defendantâ€™s absence and the
  consequent lapse of timeâ€); State v. Goree, 659 N.W.2d 344, 348-49 (Neb.
  Ct. App. 2003) (discussing cases in which appeals were dismissed based on the
  appellantâ€™s fugitive status prior to commencement of the appeal); State v.
    Lundahl, 882 P.2d 644 (Or. Ct. App. 1994) (upholding the dismissal of
  defendantâ€™s appeal where defendantâ€™s seven-year fugitive status significantly
  interfered with appellate process); cf. Lamb v. State, 293 S.C.
  174, 359 S.E.2d 282 (1987); Martin v. State, 276 S.C. 514, 280 S.E.2d
  210 (1981); and State v. Johnson, 44 S.C. 556, 21 S.E. 806 (1895) (all dismissing
  the appeals of escapees who fled during pendency of their appeal).Â  Accordingly,
  Serretteâ€™s appeal is hereby
DISMISSED.
HEARN, C.J.,
  KITTREDGE, J., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

[1] During the ten-year interim between the trial and
  sentencing, Serretteâ€™s trial counsel passed away.

title: Dalton v. State
description: In this PCR proceeding, Dalton argued his guilty plea was involuntary due to trial  counsel's failure to interview witnesses before advising him to plead guilty.  The PCR court granted Dalton's application for relief.  The Court of Appeals reversed the PCR court and held that the record is devoid of any probative evidence to support Dalton's post conviction relief.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Richard C.
      Dalton, Respondent, 
				v.
				State of South Carolina, Petitioner.
			
		
	


Appeal from Spartanburg County 

Roger L. Couch, Circuit Court Judge 
Post Conviction Judge
Opinion No. 4323
Submitted December 1, 2007 â€“ Filed
  December 18, 2007
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott,
  Assistant Attorney General Molly R. Crum, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
				Lanelle C. Durant, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

ANDERSON,
  J.:Â  The post-conviction
  relief (PCR) court granted Richard C. Daltonâ€™s (Dalton) application for relief
  after finding his guilty plea was involuntary due to counselâ€™s failure to
  interview witnesses.Â  This court granted the Stateâ€™s petition to review the PCR
  courtâ€™s decision. Â We reverse.[1]
FACTUAL/PROCEDURALÂ 
  BACKGROUND
Dalton was indicted
  for two counts of criminal sexual conduct with a minor second degree against
  two step-daughters, fifteen-year-old â€œChild Aâ€ and thirteen-year-old â€œChild B.â€Â 
  Respondent was represented by appointed counsel.Â  Concerning the charge
  involving Child A, Dalton pled guilty as indicted to one count of criminal
  sexual conduct with a minor second-degree on July 18, 2002.Â  He waived
  presentment on the other charge involving Child B and pled guilty to one count
  of lewd act on a minor.Â  Dalton was sentenced to: (1) twenty years for criminal
  sexual conduct with a minor second-degree, provided upon fifteen years the
  balance would be suspended with five years probation and (2) a concurrent term
  of fifteen years for lewd act on a minor.Â   
At the guilty plea
  hearing, evidence of Daltonâ€™s guilt on the charge involving Child A was
  presented.Â  The solicitor told the judge that Child A said Dalton fondled her, had
  sexual intercourse with her at least four times, and engaged in oral sex.Â  The
  judge was informed that Child B reported Dalton fondled her and made some oral
  sexual contact.Â  Dalton admitted to a Department of Social Services caseworker
  that he would â€œeat [Child A] out,â€ but he denied having sex.Â  Additionally, Dalton gave a statement to police confessing he did have sex with Child A.Â  Dalton only disagreed with the length of time over which the events occurred.
 
Daltonâ€™s counsel at
  the plea hearing indicated he had explained to Dalton the charges, the possible
  punishment, his constitutional rights including his right to a jury trial, and
  his right to present the lewd act charge to a grand jury.Â  Counsel said Dalton understood and wished to plead guilty.Â  The plea court advised Dalton that by entering
  a guilty plea he would give up his constitutional rights to (1) remain silent
  and not be compelled to testify against himself; (2) be tried by a jury of
  peers or equals to which the State would be required to prove his guilt beyond
  a reasonable doubt; and (3) confront and cross-examine witnesses presented
  against him as well as his right to call witnesses in his own behalf.Â   
Regarding
  the lewd act charge, the plea court explained it was not a lesser included
  offense of criminal sexual conduct second degree and it had not been presented
  to a grand jury. Â The court informed Dalton a grand jury could determine probable
  cause and a trial would follow, or the grand jury could return a no bill.Â  The
  plea court asked:

	
		
			Q: 
			Do you understand that process?
 
		
		
			â€¦
 
			 
		
		
			A:
			Yes, sir.
 
		
		
			Q:  
			And do you still wish to give up 
			your right of presentment of this charge to the Grand Jury.
 
		
		
			A:  
			Yes, sir.  
		
	

After
  assuring Dalton understood the constitutional rights that he would be giving up
  by pleading guilty, the colloquy continued as follows:

	
		
			Q:
			Understanding the nature of the 
			charges against you and the consequences of a guilty plea, how do 
			you plead to these charges, guilty or not guilty?
 
		
		
			A:
			Guilty.
 
		
		
			Q:
			Do you understand 
			that, when you plead guilty, that you will waive or give up any 
			possible defenses that you might have to these charges?
 
		
		
			A: 
			Yes, sir.
 
		
		
			Q: 
			And do you also understand that, 
			if youâ€™ve given an incriminating statement in this case, that, by 
			pleading guilty, that you will waive or give up the right to contest 
			or challenge whether such a statement was freely and voluntarily 
			given in accordance with your constitutional rights?
 
		
		
			A: 
			(Nods affirmatively.)
 
		
		
			Q: 
			Did you commit these offenses?
 
		
		
			A:  
			Yes, sir.  
		
	

The plea court
  asked Dalton whether he understood the recommended concurrent sentences were
  not binding and he could be sentenced to the maximum on both charges.Â  Dalton answered affirmatively.Â  The court continued:

	
		
			Q:
			You still wish to enter your 
			plea of guilty?
 
		
		
			A: 
			Yes, sir.
 
		
		
			Q:
			Now, Mr. Dalton, when you enter 
			a plea of guiltyâ€”has anyone promised you anything or threatened you 
			in order to get you to enter this plea of guilty?
 
		
		
			A:
			No, sir.
 
		
		
			Q:
			Are you entering this plea of 
			your own free will and accord?
 
		
		
			A: 
			Yes, sir, I am.
 
		
		
			Q: 
			Are you satisfied with the 
			manner in which [your counsel] has advised and represented you?
 
		
		
			A: 
			Yes, sir.
 
		
		
			Q:
			Do you need any more time to 
			speak with him?
 
		
		
			A: 
			No.
 
		
		
			Q:
			You feel that heâ€™s done 
			everything for you that he could have or should have done?
 
		
		
			A: 
			Well, heâ€™s â€“ no, not really.  
			I believe that he, he needs to bring up the fact that I know Iâ€™m 
			guilty and I admit my fault here.  But I have no criminal prior 
			record at this, this matter. I â€“
 
		
		
			Q: 
			Heâ€™s gonna
  be able to tell me that in a few minutes.
 
		
		
			â€¦
 
			 
		
		
			Q: 
			What, what Iâ€™m asking you is up 
			untilâ€”
 
		
		
			A: 
			Heâ€™s done
  his, his job very well.
 
		
		
			Q:
			All right.  All right.  
			So, youâ€™re completely satisfied with--?
 
		
		
			A: 
			Yes.
 
		
		
			Q:
			--what heâ€™s done?
 
		
		
			A:  
			Yes, sir.  
		
	

Daltonâ€™s counsel informed
  the plea court Dalton intended to plead guilty to spare the victims from having
  to testify.Â  He explained Daltonâ€™s only prior record was limited to minor
  traffic offenses, and he was working and taking care of his family when charged.Â 
  The judge was told that Dalton had developed a crack habit in the time leading
  up to the charges and this legal trouble was out of the ordinary for him.Â  The
  court accepted Daltonâ€™s guilty plea, finding it was voluntarily, knowingly and
  intelligently made, with the advice and counsel of a competent lawyer with whom
  Dalton was satisfied.Â   
Dalton failed to timely file and serve his pro se direct appeal.Â  On November 25, 2002, he filed an application for
  post-conviction relief alleging ineffective assistance of counsel and
  involuntary pleas.Â  An evidentiary hearing was held on May 28, 2004, and relief
  was granted by a written order on February 11, 2005.Â  Daltonâ€™s petition for
  appeal bond was denied by the South Carolina Supreme Court, and the State filed
  a petition for writ of certiorari.Â  Jurisdiction was transferred to this court
  on February 15, 2006.Â   
ISSUE

	Did the
  PCR court err in finding that counsel was ineffective for failing to interview
  witnesses when Dalton pled guilty?

STANDARD OF REVIEW
The proper standard of review of a post-conviction relief
  evidentiary hearing is whether â€œany evidence of probative valueâ€ exists to
  sustain the PCR judgeâ€™s findings.Â  Wicker v. State, 310 S.C. 8, 11, 425
  S.E.2d 25, 27 (1992); Cherry v. State, 300 S.C. 115, 386 S.E.2d 624
  (1989).Â  In a PCR proceeding, the applicant bears the burden of proving the
  allegations in their application.Â  Butler v. State, 286 S.C. 441,
  442, 334 S.E.2d 813, 814 (1985); Rule 71.1(e), SCRCP.
Where ineffective assistance of counsel is alleged as a ground for
  relief, the applicant must prove that â€œcounselâ€™s conduct so undermined the
  proper functioning of the adversarial process that the trial cannot be relied
  upon as having produced a just result.â€Â  Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668, 669, (1984); Butler v. State, 286 S.C. 441, 334 S.E.2d 813 (1985).Â  The
  proper measure of performance is whether the attorney provided representation
  within the range of competence required in criminal cases.Â  The courts presume
  that counsel rendered adequate assistance and made all significant decisions in
  the exercise of reasonable professional judgment.Â  Strickland, 466 U.S. at 690.Â  The applicant must overcome this presumption in order to receive relief.Â  Cherry,
  300 S.C. at 118, 386 S.E.2d at 625.Â   
A two-pronged test is used in evaluating allegations of
  ineffective assistance of counsel.Â  A PCR applicant who pleads guilty on the
  advice of counsel may collaterally attack the plea only by showing that (1)
  counsel was ineffective and (2) there is a reasonable probability that but for
  counselâ€™s errors, the applicant would not have pled guilty and would have
  insisted on going to trial.Â  Roscoe v. State, 345 S.C. 16, 20, 546
  S.E.2d 417, 419 (2001).Â  When alleging that his guilty plea was induced by
  ineffective assistance of counsel, an applicant must prove that counselâ€™s
  advice was not â€œwithin the competence demanded of attorneys in criminal
  cases.â€Â  Hill v. Lockhart, 474 U.S. 52, 56 (1985).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Dalton argued his guilty plea was involuntary due to trial
  counselâ€™s failure to interview witnesses before advising him to plead guilty.Â  In
  the order granting Daltonâ€™s application for relief, the PCR court agreed and
  annunciated in its order: Â 

	Had applicantâ€™s trial counsel consulted with the
  witnesses given him by the applicant, there is reasonable probability that
  results of proceedings could have been different.Â  As argued by Applicant,
  Trial Counselâ€™s failure to interview any of the witnesses left this Applicant
  with no defense or evidence of mitigation at trial, effectively forcing him to
  throw himself upon the mercy of the court.
	The Court finds Trial Counselâ€™s argument that it was
  needless to interview witnesses due to Applicantâ€™s Statement is not
  convincing.Â  Applicantâ€™s Statement did not address the charges comprising the
  lewd act, and was less conclusive on all elements of the CSC second degree
  charge.Â  Applicantâ€™s witness who testified at the PCR Hearing called into
  question the credibility of the complaining witness and presented facts through
  which impeachment might have been obtained.Â  Her testimony also presented other
  aspects of the events leading to the charges in a light substantially different
  from that presented by the Solicitor.Â  Trial Counsel argued that had he
  elicited such anticipated testimony it would have served to anger the Judge.Â 
  Considering Applicant is the one who received the twenty year sentence,
  Applicant should have been afforded that decision based on counselâ€™s informed
  advice after counsel had actually heard what the witnesses had to say.
	I find that Trial Counselâ€™s representation fell below
  an objective standard of reasonableness and it is a reasonable probability that
  as a result the outcome of Applicantâ€™s court appearance would have been
  different.Â  Trial Counsel was ineffective in failing to interview defense
  witnesses made known to him.Â  Consequently, Counsel was unable to objectively
  evaluate Applicantâ€™s defense and intelligently advise Applicant.Â  The negative
  effect of counselâ€™s errors amounts to deficient performance which affected the
  outcome of the Applicantâ€™s court appearance.Â  

The State contends that the PCR court
  erred in granting Dalton relief.Â  We agree.Â Â  
A guilty plea is a solemn, judicial admission of the truth of the
  charges against an individual; thus, a criminal inmateâ€™s right to contest the
  validity of such a plea is usually, but not invariably, foreclosed.Â  Blackledge
    v. Allison, 431 U.S. 63 (1977).Â  Therefore, statements made during a guilty
  plea should be considered conclusive unless a criminal inmate presents valid
  reasons why he should be allowed to depart from the truth of his statements.Â  Crawford
    v. United States, 519 F.2d 317 (4th Cir. 1975); Edmonds v. Lewis, 546 F.2d 566 (4th Cir. 1976).Â  An applicant may
  attack the voluntary, knowing, and intelligent character of a guilty plea
  entered on the advice of counsel by demonstrating that counselâ€™s representation
  was below an objective standard of reasonableness.Â  Porter v. State, 368
  S.C. 378, 383-84, 629 S.E.2d 353, 356 (2006); Roscoe v. State, 345 S.C.
  16, 20, 546 S.E.2d 417, 419 (2001).Â  The â€œprejudice,â€ requirement focuses on
  whether counselâ€™s constitutionally ineffective performance affected the outcome
  of the plea process.Â  Hill v. Lockhart, 474 U.S. 52, 59 (1985).Â  In
  other words, the applicant must prove prejudice by showing that, but for
  counselâ€™s inadequacy, there is a reasonable probability he would not have
  pleaded guilty and, instead, would have insisted on going to trial.Â  Suber
    v. State, 371 S.C. 554, 558, 640 S.E.2d 884, 886 (2007).Â  Â Â Â Â Â   
To find
  a guilty plea is voluntarily and knowingly entered into, the record must
  establish the defendant had a full understanding of the consequences of his
  plea and the charges against him.Â  Boykin v. Alabama, 395 U.S. 238, 242 (1969); Roddy v. State, 339 S.C. 29, 33-34, 528 S.E.2d 418, 421
  (2000).Â  â€œA defendantâ€™s knowing and voluntary waiver of the constitutional
  rights which accompany a guilty plea may be accomplished by colloquy between
  the Court and the defendant, between the Court and defendantâ€™s counsel, or
  both.â€Â  Pittman v. State, 337 S.C. 597, 625, 524 S.E.2d 623, 659
  (1999).Â   
â€œ[T]he
  voluntariness of a guilty plea is not determined by an examination of the
  specific inquiry made by the sentencing judge alone, but is determined from
  both the record made at the time of the entry of the guilty plea and the record
  of the post-conviction hearing.â€Â  Harres v. Leeke, 282 S.C. 131, 133,
  318 S.E.2d 360, 361 (1984).Â  â€œWhen determining issues relating to guilty pleas,
  this Court will consider the entire record, including the transcript of the
  guilty pleas and the evidence presented at the PCR hearing.â€Â  Roddy, 339
  S.C. at 33, 528 S.E.2d at 420.Â  In considering an allegation on PCR that a guilty
  plea was based on inaccurate advice of counsel, the transcript of the guilty
  plea hearing will be considered to determine whether any possible error by
  counsel was cured by the information conveyed at the plea hearing.Â  Wolfe v.
    State, 326 S.C. 158, 165, 485 S.E.2d 367, 370 (1997).Â   
1.  Ineffective
  Assistance of Counsel
The
  PCR court granted relief based solely on counselâ€™s failure to interview
  witnesses.Â  Despite Daltonâ€™s statements to police and to DSS and his telling
  appointed counsel his crack habit caused him to act out of character, Dalton
  avers this failure forced him to plead guilty because it left him without any
  defense.Â   
At
  the PCR hearing, Dalton maintained three witnesses could have helped his case:Â 
  Faith Dalton (Faith), his ex-wife and mother of Child B; Sonya Cowart, his
  sister with whom he was living when charges were filed; and Tom Scruggs, his former
  employer.Â  Daltonâ€™s attorney questioned him on the support these witnesses
  could have provided.

	
		
			Q:  
			And the question is, had he 
			contacted the witnesses what would he have learned that would have 
			helped your case?
 
		
		
			A:
			I donâ€™t know, Iâ€™m not my 
			witnesses, I donâ€™t know what they know.  But I know that I was 
			going to use them as my witnesses.
		
	

Dalton gave only general statements about how the women
  would have supported his case and he did not discuss Scruggs.Â  He stated Faith,
  the complainant on Child Bâ€™s incident report, lived with Child B and knew of her
  â€œactivities and veracityâ€; and his sister would have been a beneficial witness
  because she had been around him and the child and knew of the childâ€™s â€œactivities.â€ 

Daltonâ€™s appointed counsel admitted Dalton had expressed
  concern over the victimâ€™s dress and manner of conduct both in his statement to
  police and in their conversations.Â  From the record, it appears this discussion
  concerned Child A.Â  Counsel reasoned this was inadmissible, not a defense to
  having sex with a person under the age of sixteen, and possibly harmful to Daltonâ€™s case.Â  Given the substantial evidence against Dalton, counsel focused on reducing
  the charges which carried a possible sentence of fifty-five years.Â  Daltonâ€™s PCR counsel only lightly addressed the witness issue when he asked appointed
  counsel:

	
		
			Q: 
			And did he ever provide you with the names of 
			potential defense witnesses?
 
		
		
			A: 
			We talked about numerous witnesses.  I 
			looked through my file, I didnâ€™t have a list of thirty-three, but 
			there was a lot.  But the thing about his witnesses were as the 
			witnesses testified in his statement and the victimâ€™s statement they 
			both say they were the only ones there.  He had no witnesses 
			who were going to say, â€œWell, I was there and it didnâ€™t happen.â€  
			All of his witnesses revolved around the fact that the girl 
			conducted herself in what they felt was in an inappropriate manner, 
			which is of no help and no use.
		
	

We
  do not agree with the PCR court that Dalton established ineffective assistance
  of his court appointed attorney.Â  The transcript of the guilty plea clearly
  refutes Daltonâ€™s assertion that he believed he had a defense.Â  At the PCR
  hearing, he was unable to explain how he would have benefited from these
  witnessesâ€™ testimony.Â  See Jackson v. State, 329 S.C. 345,
  353-54, S.E.2d 768, 772 (1998) (counsel not proven ineffective where
  â€œrespondent failed to present any evidence of what counsel would have
  discovered or what other defenses respondent would have requested counsel
  pursue had counsel more fully prepared for trialâ€); Moorehead v. State,
  329 S.C. 329, 496 S.E.2d 415 (1998) (â€œfailure to conduct an independent
  investigation does not constitute ineffective assistance of counsel when the
  allegation is supported only by mere speculation as to the result.â€); see also Glover v. State, 318 S.C. 496, 458 S.E.2d 538 (1995)
  (counsel not ineffective where witnessesâ€™ testimony at PCR hearing not
  favorable to applicantâ€™s alibi defense).Â   
The
  plea colloquy record indicates Dalton was fully informed of his constitutional
  rights, understood the charges, and was cognizant of the maximum sentences he
  could receive.Â  Specifically, Dalton told the plea judge he understood by
  pleading guilty he would be waiving any possible defenses.Â   
2.  Prejudice
The
  PCR court order articulated the speculative notion that had â€œwitnessesâ€ been
  interviewed, â€œthere is a reasonable probability that results of the proceedings
  would be different.â€Â  In our view, Dalton failed to prove he was prejudiced by
  the performance of his court appointed counsel.Â   
Of
  the three witnesses Dalton identified as potentially helpful at the PCR
  hearing, only Faith testified.Â  Faith and Dalton have four children together.Â 
  When the charges were filed, their three boys lived with Dalton and were placed
  in foster care. At the PCR hearing, Faith Dalton testified:

	
		
			Q: 
			Do you knowâ€”did you know 
			anything about any of the facts as far as the physical facts of what 
			may or may not have happened?
 
		
		
			A:
			No, sir.
 
		
		
			Q: 
			Okay.  Do you have any 
			knowledge concerning [Child Bâ€™s] truthfulness?
 
		
		
			A:
			Yes, sir.
 
		
		
			Q:
			Well, based on your having lived 
			with [Child B] and raised her, what is your opinion as to her 
			truthfulness?
 
		
		
			A:
			[Child B] is a veryâ€”until this 
			day is a very dramatic person.  She does not tell full truths.  
			She can come up with a story off a limb and make you believe it.  
			She can cry at the drop of a dime.  She has done this numerous 
			times throughout her life even as a small child.  That is what 
			has made it hard for me to believe that what [Child B] has stated 
			against Richard Dalton, my ex-husband, is difficult to believe, not 
			only because of her inability to be truthful but also her demeanor 
			of how she handles situations.  She is the type of child that 
			if she donâ€™t want you to touch her sheâ€™s going to let you know, 
			sheâ€™s going to do something about it.  If she doesnâ€™t like what 
			you say sheâ€™s going to come to a defensive act, be it verbally or 
			physically.  
 
		
		
			â€¦
 
			 
		
		
			 Q: 
			Youâ€™re saying sheâ€™s not a shrink 
			in the wall flower [sic]?
 
		
		
			A:  
			No, sheâ€™s not.
 
		
		
			Q: 
			Now, things you just told me, 
			did you tell anyone in connection with the case about those?
 
		
		
			A: 
			I didnâ€™t speak to anybody on 
			Richardâ€™s behalf, I spoke to DSS case workers and that was it.Â  That is the only people that I
  spoke to and they wouldnâ€™t listen to anything I had to say.
 
		
		
			â€¦
 
			 
		
		
			Q:
			Were you there when Mr. Dalton 
			pled?  
 
		
		
			A:
			Yes, sir, I was.
 
		
		
			Q: 
			Did the trial judge give you an 
			opportunity to say anything?
 
		
		
			A:  
			The trial judge did, yes, sir.
 
		
		
			Q: 
			Did you take that opportunity?
 
		
		
			A:  
			No, sir.
 
		
		
			Q: 
			Why not?
 
		
		
			A: 
			Because the solicitor instructed 
			me not to say anything at the trial due to the fact that I was 
			fighting for custody of my children, and that if I said anything on 
			behalf of Richard Dalton that I would not regain custody of my three 
			boys, that they would remain in foster care.
		
	

Faith
  further stated she could have testified to Daltonâ€™s condition when he wrote the
  statement.Â  She explained that he had a drug problem and often didnâ€™t remember
  what he had done.[2]Â 
  However, on cross-examination, Faith admitted she was not present when Dalton gave his statement nor were they living together.Â  From her testimony, the PCR judge
  held she offered facts through which Child B could be impeached.Â  He
  additionally found the testimony contained â€œother aspects of the events leading
  to the charges in a light substantially different from that presented by the
  Solicitor.â€
We
  disagree and find no probative evidence in this testimony to support the PCR
  judgeâ€™s findings, especially with the plea on the charge involving Child A.Â  Cherry
    v. State, 300 S.C. 115, 386 S.E.2d 624 (1989).Â  Faith attended Daltonâ€™s plea hearing but chose not to speak. Â Daltonâ€™s testimony that his sister knew of Child
  Bâ€™s activities did nothing to carry his burden.Â  â€œThis Court has repeatedly held a PCR applicant must
  produce the testimony of a favorable witness or otherwise offer the testimony
  in accordance with the rules of evidence at the PCR hearing in order to establish
  prejudice from the witnessâ€™ failure to testify at trial.â€Â  Bannister v.
    State, 333 S.C. 298, 303, 509 S.E.2d 807, 809 (1998); see, e.g., Pauling
      v. State, 331 S.C. 606, 503 S.E.2d 468 (1998); Glover v. State, 318
  S.C. 496, 458 S.E.2d 538 (1995); Underwood v. State, 309 S.C. 560, 425
  S.E.2d 20 (1992); Jackson v. State, 329 S.C. 345, 495 S.E.2d 768
  (1998).Â  Mere speculation of what a witnessâ€™ testimony may be is insufficient
  to satisfy the burden of showing prejudice in a petition for PCR.Â  Porter v.
    State, 368 S.C. 378, 386-87, 629 S.E.2d 353, 358 (2006) (holding no
  evidence showed counselâ€™s failure to interview a potential witness would have
  yielded a result different from that which defendantâ€™s counsel believed at the
  time of the plea; defendant pled guilty in light of the complete information
  that was available at that time).  
CONCLUSION
Although
  this court generally affords great deference to the PCR courtâ€™s findings, in
  this case we conclude the record is devoid of any probative evidence to support
  Daltonâ€™s post-conviction relief.Â  Accordingly, we REVERSE the decision
  of the PCR court and REINSTATE Daltonâ€™s guilty plea and sentences.
KITTREDGE
  and SHORT, JJ. concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument, pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Â At the PCR hearing, Dalton testified he told
  appointed counsel he was under the influence of cocaine when he gave his
  statement to the police and that he did not remember writing it.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				
				Kim Parrish, Appellant,
				v.
				Earl
      Allison, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal from Laurens County
Alison Renee Lee, Circuit Court Judge 
Opinion No. 4322
Heard November 14, 2007 â€“ Filed December

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND
  REMANDED


	
		
			
				J. Michael Turner, Sr., and Matthew P. Turner, of Laurens, for
  Appellant.
				Frank L. Eppes and L. Lee Plumblee, of Greenville, for Respondent.
			
		
	

ANDERSON,
  J.:Â  In this defamation
  action, Kim Parrish (Parrish) sued Earl Allison (Allison) for statements
  alleged to be slander per se.Â  The trial court denied Parrishâ€™s motions
  for directed verdict and judgment notwithstanding the verdict.Â  The jury returned
  a verdict for Allison.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.
FACTUAL /
  PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Appellant
  Parrish is the great-niece of Allison.Â  Over the years, family disagreements
  have resulted in numerous insinuations and incidents by both sides.Â  Frequently
  at issue was the family land which has been divided over time between Allison,
  Parrish, and others.Â  The events leading to this defamation action arose when
  Parrish began efforts to have the county close a portion of road where her land
  is located.Â  At a Laurens County Council (the Council) meeting, Parrish
  appeared and voiced her concerns regarding the safety of the road.Â  Allison
  expressed his opposition at a subsequent council meeting where he made the
  statements at issue.Â  Specifically, Allison said Parrish had (a) â€œconned his
  mother [Parrishâ€™s great-grandmother] into signing her land over to [Parrish],â€
  and (b) â€œconned [his mother] out of her insurance money.â€
Prior
  to the meetings, Parrish visited Allison at his home to discuss her intentions
  to ask the county to close the road.Â  Although Allison initially told Parrish
  he was neutral, he later decided to oppose the closing.Â  Allisonâ€™s change in
  position was sparked by an article he read in the local newspaper.Â  It reported
  that Parrish, at the first meeting, told the Council a man fell off a golf cart
  and was run over on the road.Â  Allison knew this incident never happened.Â 
  However, Parrishâ€™s testimony revealed her nephew fell off a go-cart in another
  locale and was run over leaving him with a lengthy recovery.Â  The record
  established that the newspaper had misquoted Parrish.Â  At trial, Parrish said
  she told the Council of her nephewâ€™s ordeal to illuminate the devastation of
  â€œfreak accidents.â€Â   
At the inception of the second county council meeting, an
  announcement was made clarifying the newspaper had reported incorrectly.Â 
  Allison, advanced in years and hard of hearing, was present but testified
  repeatedly he did not hear the correction.Â  He proceeded to make his statements
  believing Parrish had told a lie and the Council would rely on a fabrication in deciding whether to
  close the road.Â  Allison made
  the following statements about Parrish: â€œShe lied about different things . . .
  .Â  [S]he lied about a man getting ran over.â€Â   

	I donâ€™t know why she is driving this so
  hard with lies to get it accomplished.Â  [T]he point about the man getting run
  over on Allison Road is an absolute lie.Â  This is the most outrageous thing I
  have ever heard.Â  This should have been kicked out the first time she came in
  here with this big tale.Â  We have had trouble with this woman ever since she
  has been living in Hickory Tavern.Â  The things that she has done and gotten by
  with . . . . she got by with cutting Tony Lollis water line and blocking the
  road off.Â  I want to tell you how kind-hearted she is.Â  My mother lived to be
  an old, old woman.Â  She conned her into signing the whole place . . . house,
    land and furniture, two insurance policies.Â  She did not show up at the
  funeral.Â  She did not show up at the Mortuary and paid not one penny towards
  the funeral.Â  The two insurance policies were for her funeral.Â  She is a
  dangerous woman.Â  (Emphasis supplied).

Allison does not deny making the statements though testimony is
  inconsistent as to whether he used â€œconnedâ€ to imply â€œstoleâ€ or â€œpersuaded.â€Â  In a deposition, Allison insisted on the
  truth of his statements and answered the questions of Parrishâ€™s attorney as
  follows:

	
		
			Q: 
			You wanted her to be known as a 
			liar in the community?
 
		
		
			A: 
			Right.
 
		
		
			Q:
			You wanted her to be known as 
			someone who stole land from your mother?
 
		
		
			A: 
			Right.  Exactly right.
		
	
	But
  on direct examination by Parrishâ€™s attorney, Allison testified:
	
		
			Q:
			Now, Mr. Allison, when you appeared before the
  Laurens County Council you could have spoken against the closing of Allison Road without personally attacking Kim Parrish, couldnâ€™t you?
 
		
		
			A: 
			Say
  I could have?
 
		
		
			Q:
			Yes,
  sir.
 
		
		
			A:
			Well, I wanted to get the point across, I
  wanted her character revealed and I wanted to let the county council know what
  we were dealing with.Â  
 
		
		
			Q: 
			You
  turned this into a personal attack on Kim Parrish?
 
		
		
			A: 
			No, no, no.Â  I have no personal attack on
  Kim.Â  I am glad to see Kim progress, the way they are progressing.Â  I donâ€™t
  hate my own, I donâ€™t mean to hate you and I donâ€™t know what you are up to.Â  I
  hateâ€”
 
		
		
			 
			Q:Â  Â Â Â  Well, I am sorry if you feel like I am up to
  something, I am just here asking questions.Â  What I want to know is the truth
  about this matter and this.Â  You could have spoken against the closing of the
  road without calling Kim Parrish a liar, couldnâ€™t?
 
		
		
			A: 
			Well, I thought it would be best to reveal her
  character and let the county council know that the road shouldnâ€™t be closed on
  that statement, that a man was run over.
 
		
		
			. .
  . 
 
			 
		
		
			Q:
			Well,
  lets [sic] talk about what you did say, okay?
 
		
		
			A: 
			Alright.
 
		
		
			Q:
			Alright,
  we know you called her a liar, correct?
 
		
		
			A: 
			Did
  I call her a liar?
 
		
		
			Q:
			Yes,
  sir.
 
		
		
			A: 
			Well, I didnâ€™t mean to damage her character.Â 
  All I meant was to get it across to the county council that we were dealing
  with an unreliable person, in the newspaper.
 
		
		
			Q:
			Now, you also, I believe, said that she conned
  your mother into signing the whole place over to her, didnâ€™t you?
 
		
		
			A: 
			I
  believe I did say that.
 
		
		
			Q:
			And
  her insurance money too, didnâ€™t you?
 
		
		
			A: 
			And
  you know what my basis forâ€”
 
		
		
			Q:
			What
  I am saying, and insurance money too, correct?
 
		
		
			A: 
			Right,
  right.
 
		
		
			Q:
			And
  you said both of those things to county council, didnâ€™t you?
 
		
		
			A: 
			Yes.
 
		
		
			Q:
			And
  that didnâ€™t have a thing to do with closing Allison Road?
 
		
		
			A: 
			No, but it was bringing out the character,
  bringing out the character.
 
		
		
			 
			Did
  it have anything to do with closing Allison Road?
 
		
		
			A: 
			Yes,
  it did.Â  That helped keep the road open in my opinion.
 
		
		
			Q:
			Okay.Â  So, your personal attack upon her of
  telling those things was for the purpose of trying to keep the road open to
  discredit her, is that right?
 
		
		
			A: 
			I
  was trying to keep the road open, that is right.
 
		
		
			Q:
			And
  trying to discredit Kim Parrish?
 
		
		
			A: 
			I wasnâ€™t trying to discredit her or anything.Â 
  I was just bringing out the straight facts.
 
		
		
			Q:
			Just
  bringing out the straight facts?
 
		
		
			A: 
			Right.
 
		
		
			Q:
			And
  you wanted the county councilâ€”
 
		
		
			A: 
			To
  believe that she was an unreliable person.
 
		
		
			Q:
			And you wanted the county council and all of
  those persons in attendance and whoever may hear this, whether it be on TV or
  otherwise to believe that she was a person who stole your motherâ€™s land, didnâ€™t
  you?
 
		
		
			A:

  statements charged Parrish with the commission of a crime of moral turpitude.Â  See Flowers v. Price, 192 S.C. 373, 378, 6 S.E.2d 750, 752 (1940)
  (considering extrinsic circumstances to determine if words are slanderous per se).Â 
  At the meeting, Allison stated that Parrish â€œconnedâ€ his mother into signing
  over her land and â€œconnedâ€ her out of her insurance money.Â  Extrinsic
  circumstances included Allisonâ€™s intent to discredit Parrish by many references
  to her alleged dishonesty including the statement that she was a liar.Â  The
  words spoken are actionable if they
  convey to the minds of the listeners, and would naturally be understood to
  mean, the plaintiff has committed a crime.Â  Id. at 377, 6 S.E.2d at 752. Â Any words actually or impliedly stating the plaintiffâ€™s guilt, or
  raising a strong suspicion of it in the minds of the hearers, are sufficient.Â  Porter
    v. News & Courier Co., 237 S.C.
  102, 108, 115 S.E.2d 656, 658 (1960).Â  See Herring v.
    Lawrence Warehouse Co., 222 S.C. 226, 235, 72 S.E.2d 453, 455 (1952)
  (finding statement that an employee is â€œshort,â€ made during an audit and
  coupled with immediate firing, actionable per se).Â   
Considering the
  context in which Allisonâ€™s statements were made, I conclude the statement that
  Parrish â€œconnedâ€ Allisonâ€™s mother out of her house and insurance money charged
  Parrish with the commission of a crime of moral turpitude such as obtaining
  property by false pretenses.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-13-240 (2003) (â€œA
  person who by false pretense or representation . . . obtains from another
  person any . . . money . . . or other property . . . is guilty of a: (1) felony
  . . . if the value of the property is five thousand dollars or more .Â  . .
  .â€).Â  Obtaining property under false pretenses is a crime of moral turpitude.Â  State
    v. Moore, 128 S.C. 192, 199, 122 S.E. 672, 674 (1924); Carruth v. Brown,
  415 S.E.2d 470, 471 (Ga. Ct. App. 1992).Â  Under these circumstances, I find Allisonâ€™s statements charged
  Parrish with the commission of a crime of moral turpitude and the trial court
  erred in denying Parrishâ€™s motion for a directed verdict on the issue of
  slander per se.

[1]Â  Innuendo is extrinsic evidence used to prove a statement's
  defamatory nature.Â  50 Am. Jur. 2d Libel and Slander Â§ 137 (1995). It
  includes the aid of inducements, colloquialisms, and explanatory
  circumstances.Â  Lily
    v. Belkâ€™s Depâ€™t Store,
  178 S.C. 278, 182 S.E.2d 889 (1935).
