description: In this workersâ€™ compensation case, the Appellants raise two issues: (1) Was the Appellate Panelâ€™s conclusion supported by substantial evidence? (2) Did the Claimantâ€™s injury satisfy the requirements of Â§ 42-1-160 and applicable case law?
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Jerry Danny
      Hall, Employee, Respondent,
				v.
				Desert Aire,
      Inc., Employer and Travelers Casualty & Surety Co., Carrier, Appellants.
			
		
	


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Mikell R. Scarborough, Special Circuit
  Court Judge
Opinion No. 4324
Heard December 13, 2007 â€“ Filed December
  20, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				F. Reid Warder, Jr., of Charleston, for
  Employer/Carrier/ Appellants.
				Malcolm M. Crosland, Jr., of Charleston, for Respondent,
			
		
	

ANDERSON,
  J.:Â Â  Claimant Jerry
  Danny Hall (Hall) sustained injuries as a result of a motor vehicle accident
  that occurred while he was traveling on a business trip.Â  The Appellate Panel
  awarded workersâ€™ compensation benefits, and the circuit court affirmed.Â 
  Employer and insurance carrier (collectively â€œDesert Aireâ€) appeal on the
  ground Hallâ€™s injury did not arise out of and in the course of his employment.Â 
  We affirm.  
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL
  BACKGROUND
Hall
  began working for Desert Aire in 1997 as regional sales manager and was
  national sales manager at the time of his injury.Â  Desert Aire manufactures and
  sells industrial and commercial dehumidification equipment.Â  The corporation
  markets its product through independent sales companies that represent Desert
  Aireâ€™s equipment to prospective buyers.Â  In addition, Desert Aire promotes
  sales by encouraging the engineers who design large facilities to include
  Desert Aire equipment in their specifications.Â Â   
As the
  national sales manager for Desert Aire, Hall was responsible for training
  Desert Aireâ€™s regional sales staff and independent sales representatives.Â  He
  routinely interacted with sales agents and engineers to facilitate the sale and
  specification of Desert Aire units.Â  Because the sales and engineering firms
  are located throughout the country, Hallâ€™s employment necessitated an average
  of four days of business travel every week.Â Â   
Hallâ€™s
  duties included entertaining potential customers and engineers who might
  recommend the companyâ€™s product.Â  In addition, he regularly conducted training
  for sales agents during business luncheons and dinners.Â  Alcohol was frequently
  served at these functions, which were organized, sponsored, and paid for by
  Desert Aire.Â  Hall had an entertainment budget designed specifically for
  entertaining prospective sales contacts and training sales agents.Â  He
  confirmed that serving alcohol at these business events was common practice,
  â€œpart of the culture of the business, in general.â€Â  Hall testified:Â  â€œThe HVAC industry, the architectural
  products when you are getting the products specified has almost always used
  entertainment, dinners, and a lot of people drink alcohol socially and lightens
  up an [sic] you talk more freely.â€
In July
  of 2004 Hall flew to Little Rock, Arkansas, to meet with agents of Air Tech,
  Inc., one of the independent sales companies that sold Desert Aire products.Â 
  The purpose of his trip was to work with the sales representatives, to visit
  with key engineers, and to plan a strategy for securing the Walmart account.Â 
  From Arkansas, Hall intended to continue his business travel to Omaha, Nebraska and Des Moines, Iowa.Â  He envisioned the excursion would last a little
  over a week.Â  Hall averred every aspect of his journey was for Desert Aire
  sales-related business; no part of his trip was for a personal purpose.
In Arkansas, Hall worked closely with Charlie Brunner, a sales agent for Air Tech.Â  On July
  16, 2004, Hall and his business associates scheduled a dinner meeting at the
  Brunner home.Â  In attendance, in addition to Hall and Brunner, were John
  Oliver, Air Tech owner, Charlotte Brunner, Air Tech sales associate, and Edward Osterman, Desert Aire regional sales manager.Â  Hall maintains the discussion
  throughout the evening focused on Desert Aire sales, including long-term plans
  and strategies for obtaining the Walmart account.Â  Hall and Brunner both
  consumed alcohol before and during the dinner meeting.Â   
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Hall
  asserts the business discussion persisted after the meal ended.Â  He and Brunner
  walked outside and around Brunnerâ€™s yard, â€œstill discussing things.â€Â 
  Eventually, they decided to change venue and continue talking while riding
  around the block in Brunnerâ€™s jeep.Â  Brunner drove and Hall occupied the front
  passenger seat.Â  Approximately 300 yards from Brunnerâ€™s home, the jeep
  overturned and Hall sustained multiple injuries that required extended
  hospitalization and medical treatment.Â  Brunner suffered fatal injuries. 
 
Hall
  sought workersâ€™ compensation benefits and Desert Aire denied his claim,
  alleging Hallâ€™s injuries did not arise out of and in the course of his
  employment.Â  The single commissioner found Hallâ€™s claim compensable, deciding
  Hall had not deviated from the course and scope of his employment at the time
  of his accident.Â  The single commissioner added: â€œ[e]ven if Hallâ€™s departure
  from the Brunner home on the evening of the accident were a deviation from his
  employment (which I find specifically was not the case) such a deviation was minimal
  and did not remove Hall from continuing to act within the course and scope of
  his employment at the time of the accident.â€Â   
The
  Appellate Panel unanimously affirmed the single commissionerâ€™s findings of fact
  and conclusions of law, adopting the order in its entirety and incorporating it
  by reference.Â  The circuit court affirmed the decision of the Appellate Panel,
  with one exception.Â  The finding by the Appellate Panel that Hall suffered an
  injury to his neck and left leg as a result of the compensable accident was
  reversed.[1]Â   
ISSUE
Does
  substantial evidence support the factual finding that Hallâ€™s injury arose out
  of and in the course of his employment, concomitantly satisfying the legal
  standard for compensability under section 42-1-160 of the South Carolina Code
  of Laws?
STANDARD OF
  REVIEW
The South Carolina Administrative Procedures Act (APA) establishes
  the standard for judicial review of decisions of the Workersâ€™ Compensation
  Commission.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 134, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306
  (1981); Gray v. Club Group, Ltd., 339 S.C. 173, 182, 528 S.E.2d 435, 440 (Ct. App.
  2000) (cert denied); Hargrove v. Titan Textile Co., 360 S.C. 276, 288, 599 S.E.2d 604, 610 (Ct. App. 2004); Gibson
    v. Spartanburg Sch. Dist. No. 3, 338 S.C. 510, 516, 526 S.E.2d 725, 728
  (Ct. App. 2000).Â  As provided by the APA, a reviewing court  

	may not substitute its judgment for the judgment of the agency as
  to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact. Â The court may affirm the
  decision of the agency or remand the case for further proceedings.Â  The court
  may reverse or modify the decision if substantial rights of the appellant have
  been prejudiced because the administrative findings, inferences, conclusions or
  decisions are affected by other error of law; [or] are clearly erroneous in
  view of the reliable, probative and substantial evidence on the whole record.Â  
	

S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  1-23-380(A)(5)(d)(e)(Supp. 2006); see also Hall v. United Rentals,
    Inc., 371 S.C. 69, 77, 636 S.E.2d 876, 881 (Ct. App. 2006); Bass v. Kenco Group, 366 S.C. 450, 456, 622 S.E.2d 577, 580
  (Ct. App. 2005);Â  Liberty Mut. Ins. Co. v. S.C. Second Injury Fund,
  363 S.C. 612, 619, 611 S.E.2d 297, 300 (Ct. App. 2005) cert. denied,
  July 2007.  
Pursuant
  to the APA, this courtâ€™s review is limited to deciding whether the Appellate
  Panelâ€™s decision is unsupported by substantial evidence or is controlled by
  some error of law.Â  Grant v. Grant Textiles, 372 S.C. 196, 200, 641
  S.E.2d 869, 871 (2007); Gibson, 338 S.C. at 516, 526 S.E.2d at 728.Â 
  â€œAny review of the Appellate Panelâ€™s factual findings is governed by the substantial
  evidence standard.â€ Â Lockridge v. Santens of Am., Inc., 344 S.C. 511,
  515, 544 S.E.2d 842, 844 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  The Appellate Panelâ€™s decision must
  be affirmed if supported by substantial evidence in the record.Â  Shuler v.
    Gregory Elec., 366 S.C. 435, 440, 622 S.E.2d 569, 571 (Ct. App. 2005)
  (citing Sharpe v. Case Produce, Inc., 336 S.C. 154, 160, 519 S.E.2d 102,
  105 (1999)).Â  It is not within the reviewing courtâ€™s province to reverse
  findings of the Appellate Panel which are supported by substantial evidence.Â  Frame
    v. Resort Servs., Inc., 357 S.C. 520, 528, 593 S.E.2d 491, 495 (Ct. App. 2004); Broughton v. South of the Border, 336 S.C. 488, 496, 520 S.E.2d 634, 637
  (Ct. App. 1999).Â  The findings of an administrative agency are presumed correct
  and will be set aside only if unsupported by substantial evidence.Â  Kenco
    Group, 366 S.C. at 458, 622 S.E.2d at 581; Frame, 357 S.C. at 528,
  593 S.E.2d at 495; Broughton, 336 S.C. at 496, 520 S.E.2d at 637.
Substantial evidence is not a mere scintilla of evidence, nor the
  evidence viewed blindly from one side of the case, but is evidence which,
  considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the
  conclusion the administrative agency reached in order to justify its action.Â  Pratt
    v. Morris Roofing, Inc., 357 S.C. 619, 594 S.E.2d 272 (2004); Jones v.
      Georgia-Pacific Corp., 355 S.C. 413, 586 S.E.2d 111 (2003).Â  Substantial
  evidence is something less than the weight of the evidence.Â  Office of
    Regulatory Staff v. S.C. Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n, 374 S.C. 46, 647 S.E.2d 223
  (2007).Â  The possibility of drawing two inconsistent conclusions from the
  evidence does not prevent an administrative agencyâ€™s findings from being
  supported by substantial evidence.Â  Sharpe, 336 S.C. at 160, 519 S.E.2d Â at
  105; Smith v. NCCI Inc., 369 S.C. 236, 247, 631 S.E.2d 268, 274 (Ct.
  App. 2006); DuRant v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 361
  S.C. 416, 420, 604 S.E.2d 704, 707 (Ct. App. 2004).Â   
The Appellate Panel is the ultimate fact finder in Workersâ€™ Compensation
  cases and is not bound by the single commissionerâ€™s findings of fact.Â  Bass
    v. Isochem, 365 S.C. 454, 468, 617 S.E.2d 369, 376 (Ct. App. 2005); Frame,
  357 S.C. at 528, 593 S.E.2d at 495; Muir v. C.R. Bard, Inc., 336 S.C.
  266, 281, 519 S.E.2d 583, 591 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  The final determination of
  witness credibility and the weight assigned to the evidence is reserved to the
  Appellate Panel.Â  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 455, 535 S.E.2d
  438, 442 (2000); Frame, 357 S.C. at 528, 593 S.E.2d at 495.Â  Where there
  are conflicts in the evidence over a factual issue, the findings of the Appellate
  Panel are conclusive.Â  Brown v. Greenwood Mills, Inc., 366 S.C. 379,
  393, 622 S.E.2d 546, 554 (Ct. App. 2005); Etheredge v. Monsanto Co., 349
  S.C. 451, 455, 562 S.E.2d 679, 681 (Ct. App. 2002); see also Mullinax
    v. Winn Dixie Stores, Inc., 318 S.C. 431, 435, 458 S.E.2d 76, 78 (Ct. App.
  1995) (â€œWhere the medical evidence conflicts, the findings of fact of the [Appellate
  Panel] are conclusive.â€).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Desert Aire contends Hallâ€™s injury did not arise out of and in the course of his
  employment.Â  We disagree.Â   
To be
  compensable, an injury by accident must be one â€œarising out of and in the
  course of employment.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-160 (Supp. 2006); Grant v.
    Grant Textiles, 372 S.C. 196, 201, 641 S.E.2d 869, 871 (2007); Broughton
      v. South of the Border, 336 S.C. 488, 496, 520 S.E.2d 634, 638 (Ct. App.
  1999).Â Â   
The
  phrase â€œarising out ofâ€ refers to the injuryâ€™s origin and cause; whereas, â€œin
  the course ofâ€ refers to the time, place, and circumstances under which the
  injury occurred. Â Baggott v. Southern Music, Inc., 330 S.C. 1, 4, 496
  S.E.2d 852, 854 (1998); Owings v.
    Anderson County Sheriffâ€™s Depâ€™t, 315
  S.C. 297, 300, 433 S.E.2d 869, 871 (1993); Loges v. Mack Truck, Inc.,
  308 S.C. 134, 138, 417 S.E.2d 538, 541 (1992).Â  Although the requirements are somewhat overlapping, they
  are not synonymous and both must exist simultaneously to allow the claimant to
  recover workersâ€™ compensation benefits. Â Osteen v. Greenville County School
    Dist., 333 S.C. 43, 49, 508 S.E.2d 21, 24 (1998); Broughton, 336
  S.C. at 496, 520 S.E.2d at 638. Â Â Â 
While an injury
  must both arise out of and in the course of employment for an employee to
  recover for an injury, â€œthere are circumstances when injuries arising out of
  acts outside the scope of the employeeâ€™s regular duties may be compensable.Â 
  These circumstances have been applied to: (1) acts benefiting co-employees; (2)
  acts benefiting customers or strangers; (3) acts benefiting the claimant; and
  (4) acts benefiting the employer privately.â€Â  Grant, 372 S.C. 196, 202,
  641 S.E.2d at 872.Â   
Whether
  an accident arises out of and is in the course and scope of employment is
  largely a question of fact for the Appellate Panel. Â Pratt v. Morris
    Roofing, Inc., 357 S.C. 619, 622, 594 S.E.2d 272, 274 (2004); Gibson v. Spartanburg Sch. Dist. No. 3, 338 S.C. 510, 518, 526 S.E.2d 725, 729 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  The
  claimant has the burden of proving facts sufficient to allow recovery under the
  Act.Â  West v. Alliance Capital, 368 S.C. 246, 252, 628 S.E.2d 279, 282
  (Ct. App. 2006).Â  However, when the facts are undisputed, whether an accident
  is compensable is a question of law.Â  Shuler v. Gregory Elec., 366 S.C.
  435, 622 S.E.2d 569 (Ct. App. 2005); Gibson, 338 S.C. at 518, 526 S.E.2d
  at 729.Â   
In determining if
  an accident arose out of and in the course of employment, each case must be
  decided with reference to its own attendant circumstances.Â  Lanford v. Clinton Cotton Mills, 204 S.C. 423, 425, 30 S.E.2d 36, 41 (1944).Â  The general policy
  in South Carolina is to construe the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act in favor of
  coverage, and any reasonable doubts as to construction should be resolved in
  favor of the claimant.Â  Davis v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Corr., 289 S.C.
  123, 125, 345 S.E2d 245, 246 (1986).  
A.  RaisonÂ  dâ€™etre mandated under section 42-1-160 for compensability.
Desert Aire contends Hallâ€™s employment did not proximately cause his injuries because
  the accident occurred during the jeep ride, while both Brunner and Hall were
  intoxicated and incapable of meaningful business discussions.Â  We disagree.
An
  accident arises out of employment when the employment is a contributing
  proximate cause of the accident.Â  Simmons v. City of Charleston, 349
  S.C. 64, 72, 562 S.E.2d 476, 480 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  It must be apparent to the
  rational mind, considering all the circumstances, that a causal relationship
  exists between the conditions under which the work is performed and the
  resulting injury.Â  Smith v. NCCI, Inc., 369 S.C. 236, 253, 631 S.E.2d
  268, 277 (Ct. App. 2006); Broughton v. South of the Border, 336 S.C.
  488, 497, 520 S.E.2d 634, 638 (Ct. App. 1999).Â   
â€œ[I]f
  the injury can be seen to have followed as a natural incident of the work and
  to have been contemplated by a reasonable person familiar with the whole
  situation as a result of the exposure occasioned by the nature of the
  employment, then it arises â€˜out ofâ€™ the employment.â€Â  Gray v. Club Group, Ltd.,
  339 S.C. 173, 187, 528 S.E.2d 435, 442 (Ct. App. 2000) (quoting Douglas v.
    Spartan Mills, Startex Div., 245 S.C. 265, 269, 140 S.E.2d 173, 175
  (1965)).Â  The injury must be fairly traced to the employment as a contributing
  proximate cause and cannot be the result of conditions to which the worker
  would be equally exposed outside of the employment.Â  Id.Â   

	The causative danger must be peculiar to the work and not common
  to the neighborhood. Â It must be incidental to the character of the business
  and not independent of the relation of master and servant. Â It need not have
  been foreseen or expected, but after the event it must appear to have had its
  origin in a risk connected with the employment, and to have flowed from that source
  as a rational consequence.

Id. 
In Gray,
  339 S.C. at 173, 528 S.E.2d at 435, this court upheld the award of benefits to
  an employeeâ€™s widow.Â  Gray died as a result of injuries he sustained in a motor
  vehicle accident while traveling from his home to pick up items for delivery.Â 
  He was employed by Club Group to work at Harbour Town in Hilton Head.Â  Id. at 179, 528 S.E.2d at 438.Â  Grayâ€™s duties included greeting guests, delivering
  documents, courier work, running errands, and transporting guests.Â  Id.Â  He was paid an hourly wage and normally worked Monday through Thursday, with
  Friday off.Â  Id. at 185, 528 S.E.2d at 441.Â   
A
  co-owner of Club Group engaged Gray to transport payroll materials between Henderson and Harbor Town on his day off, using his own vehicle, for a $35 fee that
  included mileage.Â  Id. at 179, 528 S.E.2d at 438.Â  The mileage was
  calculated from Grayâ€™s home in Savannah to Henderson, then to Harbour Town, back to Henderson, and then to Grayâ€™s home.Â  Id.Â  
 
The
  automobile accident occurred as Gray drove from his home in Savannah to Henderson to pick up payroll materials for his Friday job.Â  Club Group alleged his injury
  did not arise out of Grayâ€™s employment.Â  We concluded:

	There is substantial evidence in
  the record to support a finding that Gray was required to pick up his
  deliveries in the morning, and but for his employment he would not have
  been traveling to Henderson.Â  Instead, he would have been traveling to Hilton
  Head to pick up his paycheck, as was his custom prior to his employment on
  Fridays.

Id. at 187, 528 S.E.2d at 443 (emphasis
  supplied).Â  The essential function of Grayâ€™s Friday employment was travel.Â 
  Clearly, he could not accomplish his responsibilities but for his traveling.Â 
  Grayâ€™s employer specifically compensated him for his travel, based on round-trip
  mileage from Grayâ€™s home.Â  Grayâ€™s employment was, therefore, the contributing
  proximate cause of his death.
In West
  v. Alliance Capital, Alliance challenged the award of benefits to an
  injured worker who performed repairs on his own truck during working hours.Â  368
  S.C. 246, 628 S.E.2d 279 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  Alliance asserted the workerâ€™s
  activities were permissive rather than work-related.Â  Id.Â  Alliance employed West and leased his services to Meylan Enterprises.Â  Id. at 249,
  628 S.E.2d at 281.Â  The custom and practice existed at Meylanâ€™s shops of
  allowing employees, during working hours, to work on their own vehicles in the
  shop, using shop equipment. Id. at 250, 628 S.E.2d at 281.Â  Because
  Meylan lacked a sufficient number of usable vehicles, West volunteered the use
  of his truck after it was restored to operable condition.Â  Id. Â at
  252, 628 S.E.2d at 283.Â   
West
  was engaged in activities related to his employment when he sustained his
  injury. Â Meylan intended to use Westâ€™s truck following its repairs to address
  its shortage of available vehicles.Â  Id. Â Meylan authorized West to travel
  on company time and at company expense to retrieve the truck and permitted the
  truck to be kept at the shop.Â  Id. at 253, 628 S.E.2d at 283.Â  Moreover,
  Meylan understood repairs were necessary to make the truck operational.Â  Id. Affirming the award of benefits, we reasoned that â€œWestâ€™s injury arose out of
  the employment because the truck was being repaired for Meylanâ€™s benefit, using
  company resources, with Meylanâ€™s consent.Â  We conclude the record establishes
  the requisite causal connection between the working conditions and the injury.â€Â  Id.
Our
  supreme court recently reversed the denial of workersâ€™ compensation benefits in Grant v. Grant Textiles, 372 S.C. 196, 201, 641 S.E.2d 869, 872 (2007).Â 
  Grant was vice-president of a family-owned business, Grant Textiles.Â  Id. at 198, 641 S.E.2d at 870.Â  After making a business delivery, Grant drove, in a
  company-owned truck, to Clinton House and Meeting Plantation, a corporate
  hunting preserve where Grant Textiles frequently entertained clients.Â  Id. at 198-99, 641 S.E.2d at 870.Â  Grant intended to meet his father, the CEO of
  Grant Textiles, and customers who were interested in purchasing equipment from
  the company.Â  Id.
As
  Grant neared the entrance to the reserve, he swerved onto the shoulder to avoid
  hitting an object in the highway. Id. He parked at the entrance to
  Clinton House and walked back to the highway to remove the debris he believed
  was a hazard to his potential customers and the general public. Â Id.Â  A moving vehicle hit Grant and injured him.Â  Id.
The
  single commissioner awarded benefits and the Appellate Panel reversed,
  concluding â€œ(1) the accident did not arise out of Claimantâ€™s employment because
  the causative element of his accident had no connection with his employment;
  and (2) that Claimantâ€™s job duties were in no way related to road
  maintenance.â€Â  Id. at 200, 641 S.E.2d at 871.Â  The circuit court
  reversed, declaring the Appellate Panel erred in its application of the law.Â  Id. The Court of
  Appeals reversed and reinstated the decision of the Appellate Panel, holding
  Grantâ€™s injuries did not arise out of his employment with Grant Textiles
  because the cause of the accident had no relation to his regular employment
  duties.Â  Id.
The
  supreme court held the Appellate Panel erred in finding no causal connection
  between Grantâ€™s accident and his employment.Â  The accident would not have
  happened but for Grantâ€™s business trip to the Clinton House to meet his
  father and his employerâ€™s customers.Â  Id. at 202, 641 S.E.2d at 872
  (emphasis supplied).Â  Grantâ€™s business trip and the duties incidental to it
  were an integral part of his responsibility as an employee of Grant Textiles.
Contrastively,
  this court reversed the award of benefits to an employee who was injured when
  she left work to check on a sick co-worker.Â  Broughton, 336 S.C. at 488,
  520 S.E.2d at 634.Â  Upon reporting for her shift as a Kardex clerk, Broughton
  read an unaddressed note left by a co-worker indicating she was sick and wanted
  someone to check on her.Â  Id.Â  at 493, 520 S.E.2d at 636.Â  Broughtonâ€™s
  supervisors were absent, and Broughton did not exercise a supervisory role over
  any other employees. Â Id.Â  Moreover, her duties never required her to
  leave her employerâ€™s premises.Â  Id.
Without
  clocking out, Broughton decided to leave the workplace and check on the sick
  co-worker, where she fell and sustained an injury. Id.Â  at 494, 520
  S.E.2d at 637.Â  We held:Â   

	There is simply no causal connection between Broughtonâ€™s employment
  and her injury.Â  Her employment as a Kardex clerk in no way required her to
  check on sick employees.Â  The accident was not related to the performance of
  any duties as an employee by Broughton.Â  Checking on sick co-workers is not a
  job requirement of Kardex clerks. 

Id.Â  at 497-98, 520 S.E.2d at 638; see
  also Osteen v. Greenville County Sch. Dist., 333 S.C. 43, 50, 508
  S.E.2d 21, 25 (1998) (holding no causal connection existed between an
  attendance clerkâ€™s employment and her injury; â€œher employment in no way
  required her to be placing a chest full of ice, for use over the weekend, into
  the trunk of her vehicleâ€).Â   
In the
  instant case, the Appellate Panel found Hallâ€™s credible testimony indicated the
  eveningâ€™s activities were consistent with and logically related to Hallâ€™s
  employment responsibilities.Â  Like the claimants in Gray and Grant,
  Hallâ€™s purpose in traveling was wholly and exclusively in pursuit of his duties
  as national sales manager for Desert Aire.Â  Nothing in the evidentiary record
  suggests he engaged in any activities of a personal nature that might break the
  causal link between his employment and his injuries.Â  Only business associates
  attended the gathering at the Brunner home and their conversation focused on
  plans and strategies to promote the sale of Desert Aire equipment.Â  Although
  the business dinner ended at approximately 9:00 p.m., Hall and Brunner
  continued discussing their marketing plans for Desert Aire as they walked
  around the yard and eventually decided to take a drive in Brunnerâ€™s jeep.Â 
 
The
  custom and practice of Desert Aire employees was to frequently conduct the
  companyâ€™s business in the context of entertaining.Â  Desert Aire provided Hall
  with an expense account specifically for that purpose, understanding a portion
  of the funds would be spent on alcohol.Â  As part of the culture of Hallâ€™s
  company and â€œbusiness in general,â€ alcohol was served and consumed before and
  during the dinner meeting on the night of the accident.Â  Desert Aire, like
  Meylan in West, benefited from the business customs and practices
  endorsed by the employer.Â  Here, the custom and practice of conducting business
  in an entertaining environment fostered good working relationships, facilitated
  planning, and furthered Desert Aireâ€™s interests.Â   
Desert Aireâ€™s assertion that alcohol rendered Hall incapable of discussing business is
  without substantial evidentiary support.Â  Hallâ€™s blood alcohol level several
  hours following the accident was .121 percent and Brunnerâ€™s was .234 percent.Â 
  Desert Aireâ€™s expert, Dr. Roger A. Russell, opined that Brunner and Hall could
  not have had meaningful business conversation at the time of the accident due,
  in part, to intoxication.Â  Hallâ€™s expert, Dr. Robert Bennett, reported that
  meaningful business conversation requires only cognitive functioning and does
  not require motor skills.Â  Bennett submitted empirical data indicating that 50%
  of individuals are not grossly intoxicated at a blood alcohol level of .15.Â  In
  addition, he indicated that alcohol may, in fact, result in a beneficial effect
  on cognitive function.  
In
  deciding whether substantial evidence exists, it is appropriate to consider
  both lay and expert evidence.Â  Hargrove v. Titan Textile Co., 360 S.C.
  276, 296, 599 S.E.2d 604, 614 (Ct. App. 2004) (citing Sharpe v. Case
    Produce, Inc., 336 S.C. 154, 519 S.E.2d 102 (1999)).Â  Adopting the single
  commissionerâ€™s finding, the Appellate Panel placed greater weight on Dr.
  Bennettâ€™s opinion and report and Hallâ€™s credible testimony regarding the
  content of the discussions with Brunner at the time of the accident.  

	One of the bases of Dr. Russellâ€™s opinions with regard to the
  level of intoxication of Hall assumed Hall was of the same height and weight as
  Mr. Charles Brunner.Â  Hallâ€™s testimony clearly established that Mr. Brunner was
  significantly taller and over 50 pounds heavier than Hall.Â  Dr. Russellâ€™s
  opinions also assume Hall consumed as much alcohol as Mr. Brunner; however,
  there is no evidence supporting this assumption.Â  

The
  Appellate Panel concluded Hall did not consume sufficient alcohol to render him
  unable to engage in business discussions with Brunner immediately prior to the
  accident.Â  Furthermore, Desert Aireâ€™s contention that Brunnerâ€™s alleged
  intoxication proximately caused the accident is speculative.Â  The record is
  devoid of any evidence establishing why Brunnerâ€™s jeep overturned.
Hall
  was engaged in ongoing discussions with business associates involving the
  marketing and sale of Desert Aire equipment at the time of the accident.Â  But
    for these employment activities, Hall would not have traveled to Little Rock, attended the business dinner at the Brunner home, or continued his business
  conversation with Brunner on into the evening.Â  At all times during the day and
  evening Hall was executing his duties and responsibilities as national sales
  manager for Desert Aire.Â  Moreover, consuming alcohol at employer-sponsored
  functions was part of the custom and practice of the business culture, and
  Hallâ€™s job exposed him to the hazards incidental to that custom and practice.Â 
  The Appellate Panelâ€™s finding that Hallâ€™s injuries arose out of his employment
  is not clearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative, and
  substantial evidence on the whole record.Â  The record contains substantial
  evidence from which reasonable minds could conclude that Hallâ€™s employment was
  a contributing proximate cause of his accident and his resulting injuries arose
  out of his employment with Desert Aire.
B.  The
  course of employment prong of section 42-1-160.
An
  injury occurs â€œin the course ofâ€ employment when it occurs within the period of
  employment at a place where the employee reasonably may be in the performance
  of his duties and while fulfilling those duties or engaged in something
  incidental thereto. Â Baggott v. Southern Music, Inc., 330 S.C. 1, 5, 496
  S.E.2d 852, 854 (1998) (citing Beam v. State Workmenâ€™s Compensation Fund,
  261 S.C. 327, 331, 200 S.E.2d 83, 85 (1973); Gibson v. Spartanburg School
    Dist. No. 3, 338 S.C. 510, 519, 526 S.E.2d 725, 729-30 (Ct. App. 2000); Broughton v. South of the Border, 336 S.C. 488, 499, 520 S.E.2d 634, 639 (Ct. App.
  1999).Â  An employee need not
  be in the actual performance of the duties for which he was expressly employed
  in order for his injury to be â€œin the course ofâ€ employment.Â  Grant v. Grant
    Textiles, 372 S.C. 196, 201, 641 S.E.2d 869, 871 (2007); Skipper v.
      Southern Bell Tel. & Tel. Co., 271 S.C. 152, 156, 246 S.E.2d 94, 96 (1978)
  (citing Beam, 261 S.C. at 331, 200 S.E.2d at 85).Â  â€œIt is sufficient if
  the employee is engaged in a pursuit or undertaking consistent with his
  contract of hire and which in some logical manner pertains to or is incidental
  to his employment.â€ Â Skipper, 271 S.C. at 156, 246 S.E.2d at 96 (quoting Kohlmayer v. Keller, 263 N.E.2d 231, 233 (Ohio 1970)).Â  â€œAn act outside
  an employeeâ€™s regular duties which is undertaken in good faith to advance the
  employerâ€™s interest, whether or not the employeeâ€™s own assigned work is thereby
  furthered, is within the course of employment.â€ Â Grant, 372 S.C. at 202,
  641 S.E.2d at 871-72 (citing Howell v. Kash & Karry, 264 S.C. 298,
  301, 214 S.E.2d 821, 822 (1975)).Â   
It is
  well settled that â€œtraveling employees are generally within the course of their
  employment from the time they leave home on a business trip until they return,
  for the self-evident reason that the traveling itself is a large part of the
  job.â€Â  Arthur Larson, Larsonâ€™s Workerâ€™ Compensation Law, Â§ 14.01
  (Lexis-Nexis 2004).Â  However, this general rule is subject to challenge when an
  injury occurs while the employee has deviated from his business route or
  purpose.Â  See Meritt v. Smith, 269 S.C. 301, 307, 237 S.E.2d 366,
  369 (1977) (noting â€œthe trip to and from an eating establishment, as well as
  the taking of meals themselves, while on out-of-town business are within the
  course and scope of employment unless the circumstances attending the taking of
  the meal constitutes [sic] a deviationâ€).Â  Resolving this type of
  compensability issue usually hinges on whether the injury occurred during a
  â€œslightâ€ or â€œsubstantialâ€ deviation.  
Desert Aireâ€™s characterization of Hall and Brunnerâ€™s drive as a â€œdrunken joy rideâ€
  implies Hall substantially deviated from his business purpose of promoting
  Desert Aire sales.Â  In support of this contention, Desert Aire relies on Brownlee
    v. Wetterau Food Servs., 288 S.C. 82, 329 S.E.2d 694 (Ct. App. 1986); Boykin
      v. Prioleau, 255 S.C. 437, 179 S.E.2d 599 (1971); and Grice v. National
        Cash Register Co., 250 S.C. 1, 156 S.E.2d 321 (1967).Â Â   
In Brownlee,
  an employee died of injuries received while out of state at a training
  seminar.Â  288 S.C. at 83, 329 S.E.2d at 695.Â  This court affirmed the Appellate
  Panelâ€™s finding that the employee was not in the course of his employment at
  time of death.Â  Id.Â  The training seminar began each day at 7:00 in the
  morning and ended at approximately 10:00 in the evening.Â  Id. at 84, 329
  S.E.2d at 695.Â  Employees attending the seminar stayed at the motel where it
  was presented.Â  Id.Â  The fatal accident occurred at 1:55 a.m., several
  hours after the last scheduled seminar event and at some distance from the
  motel where the attendees stayed. Â Id.Â  The evidence indicated the employee, along with three other
  seminar attendees, had planned to see a movie after the seminar events.Â  Id.Â  
 
In
  affirming the denial of benefits, we determined the record lacked any evidence
  the employee died while attending either a job-related function or
  employer-sponsored event.Â  Id. at 85, 329 S.E.2d at 695.Â  Instead, substantial
  evidence showed he â€œdied while engaged in an outing that occurred after work,
  away from the premises of his employer, and at a time when his employer
  exercised no control over his activities.â€Â  Id.Â Â   
Similarly,
  in Grice, the Appellate Panel denied benefits when an employee, who was
  out of town for training, was killed while returning from a July fourth holiday
  picnic with other employees.Â  250 S.C. 1, 156 S.E.2d 321.Â  The evidence failed
  to demonstrate the employee sustained his injury in the course of his
  employment.Â  Id.Â  Co-employees, without the knowledge or endorsement of
  the employer, organized the picnic.Â  Id. at 4, 156 S.E.2d at 323.Â 
  Moreover, it was not held during regular work hours.Â  Id.Â  In affirming
  the denial of benefits, our supreme court summarized:  

	There is a total absence of any testimony tending to show that the
  accident from which deceased sustained the fatal injuries had its origin in a
  risk created by the necessity of being away from home. Â The picnic was not
  arranged, sponsored, or suggested by the employer. Â It was solely an outing
  planned by the deceased and his co-employees, taking place after work hours,
  off the premises of the employer, and during hours when the employer exercised
  no control over the employeeâ€™s activities. Â Insofar as the record discloses,
  the employer had no knowledge of the picnic.Â  The attendance of the deceased
  was purely voluntary on his part.

Id. at 5,
  156 S.E.2d at 323.Â   
Boykin
  v. Prioleau involved a wrongful death action against a deceased defendant
  whose duties required transporting younger co-employees, including Boykin, to
  their homes after work.Â  255 S.C. 437, 179 S.E.2d 599 (1971).Â  On the evening
  of the fatal accident, the defendant departed from his usual route and took the
  co-employees on a three-hour â€œjoy rideâ€ that included several stops and
  consumption of intoxicants.Â  All but one of the employees died in the
  accident.Â  The issue at trial was whether the accident occurred during a
  substantial deviation from the route delivering the employees home, or whether
  the defendant had resumed the scope and course of his employment at the time of
  the fatal accident.Â  If the defendant had returned to the course of his
  employment, workersâ€™ compensation was the exclusive remedy and the wrongful
  death action was barred.Â  The supreme court held this question was one for the
  jury and reversed the trial courtâ€™s directed verdict in the defendantâ€™s favor. 
 
Tangentially,
  the court noted the workersâ€™ compensation hearing commissioner awarded death
  benefits to Boykinâ€™s survivors.Â  The claim was settled without admission of
  liability before appeal to the Appellate Panel was heard.Â  However, the court
  did opine that a substantial deviation occurred during the drive to the
  employeesâ€™ homes:  

	The only reasonable inference from the facts which have been
  stated is that almost immediately upon driving away from his employerâ€™s place
  of business, [defendant] forsook the task assigned to him and embarked upon the
  pursuit of his own ends.Â  It is abundantly clear that while thus engaged
  [defendant] was not conducting his employerâ€™s business within the meaning of
  the statute.Â  Whether upon leaving the restaurant, several miles from the point
  of deviation, and starting back toward Columbia [defendant] resumed the scope
  and course of his employment was, at best from defendantâ€™s standpoint, a jury
  issue. Â We decide only that the court erred in resolving this issue in
  defendantâ€™s favor as a matter of law.

Hall
  cites Beam v. State Workmenâ€™s Compensation Fund, 261 S.C. 327, 200
  S.E.2d 83 (1973) in support of his contention that his injury occurred in the
  course of employment.Â  In Beam, two teachers were killed in an
  automobile accident en route from Gaffney to Columbia to attend a South
  Carolina Education Association meeting.Â  Beam, 261 S.C. at 330, 200
  S.E.2d at 85.Â  The Appellate Panel awarded workersâ€™ compensation benefits,
  finding the teachersâ€™ deaths arose out of and in the course of their
  employment.Â  Id.Â  Our supreme court affirmed, adopting the principle
  established by the Ohio Supreme Court that in order for injury or death to be
  in the â€˜course of employmentâ€™ â€œit is sufficient if the employee is engaged in a
  pursuit or undertaking consistent with his contract of hire and which in some
  logical manner pertains to or is incidental to his employment.â€Â  Id. at 332, 200 S.E.2d at 86 (quoting Kohlmayer v. Keller, 24 263 N.E.2d 231,
  233 (Ohio 1970)).Â  The evidence indicated the teachersâ€™ attendance at the
  association meeting, while not compulsory, was encouraged, and expected as part
  of their contractual obligation to participate in and attend the meetings of
  professional organizations, including those of the South Carolina Education
  Association.Â  Id. at 331, 200 S.E.2d at 85.Â  Concluding the teachers
  died in the course of their employment, the court observed â€œthey were not
  exercising a personal privilege wholly apart from their employment or their
  employerâ€™s interest, but were about the performance of an act, incidental to
  and recognized as of value by their superintendent in connection with their
  duties as high school teachers.â€Â  Id. at 333, 200 S.E.2d at 86.
We deem Brownlee, Boykin, and Grice factually and legally
  distinguishable from the instant case.Â  Though the claimants in Brownlee and Grice were out of town on business travel, their injuries did not
  result from risks created by the necessity of being away from home.Â  The events
  that led to each of the fatal accidents originated independently of any
  employeeâ€™s effort to further the interests of his employer.Â  Griceâ€™s attendance
  at a holiday picnic, Brownleeâ€™s assumed movie excursion, and the â€œjoy rideâ€
  that led to Boykinâ€™s demise, were not within periods of employment.Â  Nor did
  these claimantsâ€™ activities take place at locations where they might reasonably
  perform their duties, at a time during which they fulfilled those duties, or while
  engaged in something incidental thereto.Â   
In
  contraposition, the Appellate Panel found Hallâ€™s exclusive purpose for his trip
  to Little Rock was to represent and advance Desert Aireâ€™s interests.Â  The
  nature of Hallâ€™s employment required extensive travel.Â  His duties were
  necessarily performed in a variety of settings and during the course of an
  entire day, rather than at a time and in a location designated by his
  employer.Â  Desert Aire financially supported the custom and practice of
  entertaining sales agents, engineers, and potential customers to promote sales
  of Desert Aire equipment.Â   
Pellucidly,
  the evidentiary record exuberates that Hall was engaged in ongoing discussions
  regarding planning for sales activities on behalf of Desert Aire at the time of
  the accident.Â  The accident occurred within the period of employment, at a
  place where Hall was reasonably in the performance of his duties and was
  fulfilling those duties or engaged in activities incidental to that
  employment.Â  Like the claimants in Beam, Hall was not exercising a
  personal privilege wholly apart from Desert Aireâ€™s interests.Â  Rather, Hallâ€™s
  ongoing business discussion with Brunner was an act, incidental to and
  recognized as beneficial by Desert Aire in connection with Hallâ€™s duties as national
  sales manager.Â   
CONCLUSION
We hold
  substantial evidence supports the factual finding that Hallâ€™s injury arose out
  of and in the course of employment with Desert Aire, illatively satisfying the
  legal standard for compensability under section 42-1-160 of the South Carolina
  Code of Laws.Â   
Accordingly,
  the decision of the circuit court is  
AFFIRMED.
SHORT
  and WILLIAMS, JJ. concur.

[1]  The record indicates Hall conceded no
  compensable injuries were sustained to his neck or left leg.

text:
Dixie Bell v. Redd


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Dixie Bell, Inc., a South Carolina Corporation, 
				Respondent,
				v.
				Larry C. Redd, Larry Clifton Redd, Bruce A. Green, and Triple Crown    Land Development, LLC, Appellants.
			
		
	


Appeal from Greenwood County
Wyatt T. Saunders, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4325
Heard December 13, 2007 â€“ Filed December 20, 2007

REVERSED


	
		
			
				C. Rauch Wise, of Greenwood, for Appellants.
				Harold P. Threlkeld, of Anderson, for
  Respondent.
			
		
	


ANDERSON,
  J.:Â  Dixie Belle, Inc., (Dixie Belle)
  sued Larry C. Redd, Larry Clifton Redd, Bruce A. Green (collectively Triple
  Crownâ€™s principals), and Triple Crown Land Development, LLC (Triple Crown). Â The
  jury awarded Dixie Belle $100,000, and the trial court granted Dixie Belleâ€™s
  post-trial motion for pre-judgment interest.Â  We reverse the award of
  pre-judgment interest.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
In
  June 1999, Larry C. Redd and Larry Clifton Redd organized Triple Crown Land
  Development, LLC to buy and develop a tract of land in Aiken County, South Carolina.Â  Dixie Belle became an investor in Triple Crown, contributing $950,000 ($400,000
  cash and a $550,000 loan from Grand South Bank, secured by Dixie Belleâ€™s
  assets).
Dixie
  Belle sent Triple Crown and its principals a letter in September 2001 to
  commence negotiations to sell its interest in Triple Crown for $1,407,041.47.Â  Triple
  Crown and its principals did not respond to the letter until June 2002, when Larry
  C. Redd sought out James Forrest (Forrest), Dixie Belleâ€™s sole shareholder, to
  discuss purchasing Dixie Belleâ€™s interest in Triple Crown.Â   
Forrest
  testified he offered to sell Dixie Belleâ€™s interest for $1,412,000, the price
  in the initial letter plus interest from September to June.Â  During his cross-examination,
  Forrest explained how he reached the figure:Â  â€œYou take all those four things,
  Grand South, my money, the interest on my money, the interest on the Grand
  South note and you add ten percent to that and thatâ€™s all I wanted.â€
Larry
  C. Redd, on direct examination, asserted he and Forrest never formed an
  agreement in June 2002.Â  When asked if Forrest ever stated a price, Larry C.
  Redd answered:

	No, he
  didnâ€™t.Â  He said let him think over it, let him get back with us and he would
  get back and let us know something.Â  We didnâ€™t go back down there, my
  accountant what was with me, we didnâ€™t got back down there for a month or so.Â 
  He said, â€œI will fax you all something tomorrow,â€ but he did not do that, he
  did not do what he said he would do.

On
  August 1, 2002, Triple Crown refinanced its property with Pacific Coast
  Investments (Pacific), borrowing $5,720,000.Â  Forrest was not present at the
  closing.Â  A portion of the Pacific loan was used to satisfy Dixie Belleâ€™s debt
  with Grand South Bank in the amount of $630,559.67.Â  Both parties concede part
  of the purchase price for Dixie Belleâ€™s interest in Triple Crown would be the
  balance of the Grand South Bank loan.Â  On August 12, 2002, Dixie Belleâ€™s
  attorney was given a $527,653 check for what Triple Crown and its principals
  believed to be the remainder of Dixie Belleâ€™s interest in Triple Crown.
Dixie
  Belle declares the balance of the amount due was $782,093.33, which was $254,440.33
  more than Triple Crown and its principals tendered.Â  When a resolution could
  not be reached, Dixie Belle sued Triple Crown and its principals on March 17,
  2003, alleging four causes of action:Â  (1) declaratory judgment to determine if
  Dixie Belle had a superior lien to Pacific Coast Investment Company; (2) an
  order to allow Dixie Belle to negotiate the check for $527,653.00 without
  prejudice to the claim the check did not represent full satisfaction of the
  purchase price; (3) conversion; and (4) violation of South Carolina Uniform
  Securities Act.
The parties
  agreed to dismiss all original causes of action, and the trial court submitted
  the dispute over the purchase price to the jury based on breach of contract and
  breach of contract with fraudulent intent claims.Â  The jury returned a $100,000
  verdict for Dixie Belle.Â  In a post-trial motion, Dixie Belle moved for pre-judgment
  interest on September 20, 2005, arguing:Â   

	Defendants
  agreed, as a matter of law, to pay Plaintiff One hundred thousand dollars
  ($100,000.00) on August 1, 2002 and because the obligation to pay the One
  hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) was by agreement demandable and the sum
  was certain or capable of being reduced to certainty, Plaintiff is entitled to
  pre-judgment interest through September 15, 2005.

On
  March 6, 2006, the trial judge granted Dixie Belle $27,352 in pre-judgment interest,
  stating: â€œThe court finds and concludes that the obligation on which the
  judgment was based was fixed by conditions existing at the time the claim
  arose.â€
ISSUES

	
		
			1. 
			Did the trial court err in 
			awarding pre-judgment interest to Dixie Belle?
 
		
		
			2.
			Did Dixie Bell establish the 
			parties agreed to a sum certain, entitling it to pre-judgment 
			interest?
		
	

LAW/ANALYSIS
1.  Historic Development of
  Pre-Judgment Interest
An
  excellent academic analysis of the historic development of the law involving
  the concept and principle of pre-judgment interest is found in Vaughn
    Development, Inc. v. Westvaco Development Corp., 372 S.C. 576, 642 S.E.2d
  757 (Ct. App. 2007), which articulates:

	Historically,
  the recovery of prejudgment interest was severely limited.Â  Michael S. Knoll, 
	A
    Primer on Prejudgment Interest 75 Tex. L.Rev. 293, 294-98 (1996).Â  â€œThe
  roots of prejudgment interest law are based on centuries-old moral and
  religious proscriptions against interest and loans.Â  Both the ancient
  Israelites and Greeks viewed the taking of any interest as usurious.â€Â  Martin
  Oyos, Comment, Prejudgment Interest in South Dakota, 33 S.D. L.Rev. 484,
  485-86 (1988).Â  With the shift from agrarian economies in the common law
  European countries, and the emphasis in this country from the beginning on the
  mercantile influence, prejudgment interest has become more favored and the
  courts now allow prejudgment interest on liquidated amounts.Â  James L. Bernard,
  Note, Prejudgment Interest and the Copyright Act of 1976 5 Fordham
  Intell. Prop. Media & Ent. L.J. 427, 433 (1995).Â  There has been, however,
  â€œgrowing dissatisfaction with the distinction between liquidated and
  unliquidated damages.Â  As a result, many jurisdictions abandoned itâ€¦.Â  With the
  breakdown and rejection of the distinction between liquidated and unliquidated
  damages, courts established more liberal rules for awarding prejudgment
  interest.Â  Some courts looked to whether the claim was â€˜ascertainable.â€™â€Â  Id. at 434-436.Â  This liberalization of prejudgment law has even led to recovery of
  prejudgment interest for personal injury damages, usually calculable from the
  time of a settlement offer or demand.Â  See generally Diane M.
  Allen, Annotation, Validity and Construction of State Statute or Rule
    Allowing or Changing Rate of Prejudgment Interest in Tort Actions 40
  A.L.R.4th 147 (1985) (cases and statutes cited therein).
	Turning
  to South Carolina, we find an initial similar trend.Â  In the early part of the
  last century in South Carolina, the law regarding prejudgment interest was
  strict.Â  The failure of the party owing money to acknowledge a sum owed
  prevented a plaintiff from recovering prejudgment interest; the amount due had
  to be acknowledged and liquidated.Â  Wakefield v. Spoon, 100 S.C.
  100, 106, 84 S.E. 418, 420 (1915).Â  However, even under this specific rule, the
  law surrounding prejudgment interest was muddled.Â  Goddard v. Bulow 10
  S.C.L. (1 Nott & McC.) 45, 56 (1818) (â€œIt is not a little extraordinary
  that a question of every dayâ€™s occurrence, should have remained to this time
  unsettledâ€¦.â€).Â  Also similar to the trend in the United States, South Carolina liberalized the rules for awarding prejudgment interest.Â  The governing
  statute looks to whether the claim is ascertainable.Â  See S.C. Code Ann.
  Â§ 34-31-20(A) (Supp. 2006) (â€œIn all cases of accounts stated and in all cases
  wherein any sum or sums of money shall be ascertained and, being due, shall
  draw interest according to lawâ€¦â€).Â  â€œIn South Carolina, interest may also be
  awarded in equity cases, conversion cases, and property cases.â€Â  11 S.C. Juris.
	Damages Â§ 8 (1992).

Id. at 578-579, 642 S.E.2d at 758-759.
2.  Request for Pre-Judgment
  Interest Must Be Pled
Triple
  Crown and its principals claim the trial court erred in awarding Dixie Belle
  pre-judgment interest on the $100,000 jury verdict because Dixie Belle did not
  request pre-judgment interest in its pleadings.Â  We agree.
In Town
  of Bennettsville v. Bledsoe, 226 S.C. 214, 219, 84 S.E.2d 554, 556 (1954),
  our Supreme Court held pre-judgment interest should not be included in the
  judgment because it was not pled in the complaint or prayer.Â  Id.Â  Town
    of Bennettsville involved a claim against a contractor to recover
  overpayments made by the Town of Bennettsville on a construction contract.Â  The
  Supreme Court reversed the trial court, holding:Â  â€œThe last contention of error
  is that interest should not have been included in the judgment which was
  rendered against [Bledsoe].Â  With this we agree because interest was not
  demanded in the complaint or prayer.â€ Id. (citing Rawls v. American
    Central Ins, Co., 97 S.C. 189, 204-205, 81 S.E. 505, 510 (1914)); accord Calhoun v. Calhoun, 339 S.C. 96, 102, 529 S.E.2d 14, 18 (2000) (finding
  pre-judgment interest must be pled absent an agreement to pay a sum certain); Hopkins
    v. Hopkins, 343 S.C. 301, 307, 540 S.E.2d 454, 458 (2000); Chan v.
      Thompson, 302 S.C. 285, 293, 395 S.E.2d 731, 736 (Ct. App. 1990) (â€œThe
  Thompsons seek prejudgment interestâ€¦in their petition for rehearing.Â  The
  Thompsons neither sought nor were awarded prejudgment interest in the lower
  court.Â  They may not now raise this issue.â€).
In Goodson
  v. Carolina Container Corp., Inc., 283 S.C. 575, 324 S.E.2d 67 (1984) pre-judgment
  interest was denied when the claim demanding pre-judgment interest was stricken
  from the record:Â  â€œInasmuch as it has agreed that Goodsonâ€™s attorney consented
  to strike any reference to a claim for interest, the same should not have been
  sought at the trial level.â€Â  Id. at 577, 324 S.E.2d 68.Â  The portion of
  the trial judgeâ€™s order granting pre-judgment interest was reversed, because
  Goodson waived any claim to receive pre-judgment interest by not pleading it.Â  Id.Â  
 
An
  amendment to a complaint is sufficient to place the demand for pre-judgment
  interest before the trial judge. Â Charleston County School Dist. v. Charleston County, 297 S.C. 300, 303, 376 S.E.2d 778, 780 (1989).Â  The motion to amend,
  nevertheless, must be clear and specific to include a claim for pre-judgment
  interest.Â  McMillan v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Agric., 364 S.C. 60, 611
  S.E.2d 323 (Ct. App. 2005) cert. granted (Feb. 14, 2007).Â  In McMillan,
  counsel moved to conform the pleadings to any evidence not originally pled.Â  Id. at 75, 611 S.E.2d at 331.Â  On appeal, this Court ruled the motion to amend the
  pleadings was not sufficient to raise a pre-judgment interest claim:Â  â€œWe do
  not find the motion made by Respondents was sufficient to properly amend the
  complaint to include a claim for pre-judgment interest, which must be
  specifically pled in order to be recovered.â€Â  Id.  
In Tilley
  v. Pacesetter Corp., 355 S.C. 361, 375-376, 585 S.E.2d 292, 299 (2003), a
  class action lawsuit for violation of the Consumer Protection Code, our Supreme
  Court elucidated:

	Buyers
  argue they are entitled to prejudgment interest from October 27, 1995, the date
  the action was filed, to April 3, 1997, the date of entry of summary judgment.Â 
  We disagree.
	This
  Court requires parties to plead for pre-judgment interest in order for it to be
  recovered.Â  Hopkins v. Hopkins, 343 S.C. 301, 540 S.E.2d 454
  (2000); Calhoun v. Calhoun, 339 S.C. 96, 529 S.E.2d 14 (2000).Â  If no
  request for pre-judgment interest is made in the pleadings, it cannot be recovered
  on appeal.Â  Id.Â  If pre-judgment interest is pled for in the complaint,
  it â€œis allowed on obligations to pay money from the time the payment is
  demandable, either by agreement of the parties or by operation of law, if the
  sum is certain or capable of being reduced to certainty.â€Â  Future Group, II
    v. Nationsbank, 324 S.C. 89, 101, 478 S.E.2d 45, 50 (1996).
	In this
  case, the Buyers did not plead for pre-judgment interest in their original
  complaint of October 27, 1995, or in their amended complaint of January 23,
  1996.Â  Under the rule established in Calhoun and Hopkins, Buyers
  cannot now recover pre-judgment interest.

See Durlach v. Durlach, 596 S.C. 64, 75, 596
  S.E.2d 908, 914 (2004).
Dixie
  Belle prayed for pre-judgment interest in its original complaint.Â  Yet, Dixie
  Belle voluntarily dismissed all claims initially asserted and
  submitted its claim to the jury on a breach of contract and breach of contract
  with fraudulent intent claim, without seeking pre-judgment interest.Â  Dixie
  Belle did not place the demand for pre-judgment interest on the claims
  submitted to the jury before the trial judge and cannot recover pre-judgment
  interest because it has not been specifically pled.Â   
3.  Pre-Judgment Interest
  Awarded on a Sum Certain
Triple
  Crown and its principals aver Dixie Belle did not establish its claim was a sum
  certain and is not entitled to pre-judgment interest by statute.Â  We agree.
Section
  34-31-20(A) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006), provides statutory
  authority for pre-judgment interest:Â  â€œIn all cases of accounts stated and in
  all cases wherein any sum or sums of money shall be ascertained and, being due,
  shall draw interest according to law, the legal interest shall be at the rate
  of eight and three-fourths percent per annum.â€Â  See Jacobs v.
    American Mut. Fire Ins. Co. of Charleston, 287 S.C. 541, 545, 340 S.E.2d
  142, 144 (1986).
Our
  Supreme Court, in Llewelyn v. Dobson Bros., 274 S.C. 177, 262 S.E.2d 726
  (1980), recognized â€œ[i]n the absence of agreement or statute, interest is not
  recoverable on an unliquidated demand.â€Â  Id. at 178, 262 S.E.2d at 727
  (citing Robert E. Lee & Co., Inc. v. Comm. of Public Works of the City
    of Greenville, 248 S.C. 92, 100, 149 S.E.2d 59, 63 (1966); Ancrum v.
      Slone, 29 S.C.L. (2 Speers) 594, 596 (1844); 47 C.J.S. Interest Â§
  19(a) (1946)); Builders Transport, Inc. v. South Carolina Property &
    Cas. Ins. Guar. Assâ€™n, 307 S.C. 398, 406, 415 S.E.2d 419, 424 (Ct. App.
  1992).Â  â€œA claim is liquidated if the sum claimed is certain or capable of
  being reduced to a certainty.â€Â  Dibble v. Sumter Ice & Fuel Co., 283
  S.C. 278, 287, 322 S.E.2d 674, 679 (Ct. App. 1984) (citing Columbia Lumber
    & Mfg. Co. v. Globe Indemnity Co., 166 S.C. 408, 415, 164 S.E.2d 916, 918
  (1932); Ancrum, 29 S.C.L. (2 Speers) 594, 596; 22 Am. Jur. 2d Damages Â§ 180 (1965)); Weeks v. McMillan, 291 S.C. 287, 294, 353 S.E.2d 289, 293
  (Ct. App. 1987); Republic Textile Equipment Co. of South Carolina, Inc. v.
    Aetna Ins. Co., 293 S.C. 381, 390, 360 S.E.2d 540, 545 (Ct. App. 1987).
Not
  long ago, our Supreme Court explicated the sum certain requirement for
  pre-judgment interest in Butler Contracting, Inc. v. Court Street, LLC,
  369 S.C. 121, 631 S.E.2d 252 (2006):

	Stated
  another way, prejudgment interest is allowed on a claim of liquidated damages;
  i.e., the sum is certain or capable of being reduced to certainty based on a
  mathematical calculation previously agreed to by the parties.Â  Prejudgment
  interest is not allowed on an unliquidated claim in the absence of an agreement
  or statute.

Id. at 133, 631 S.E.2d at 258-259.Â  Finding Butler
  Contracting, Inc.â€™s claim was liquidated and a sum certain, the denial of
  pre-judgment interest was reversed.Â  Id. at 134, 631 S.E.2d at 259.Â  See Future Group, II v. Nationsbank, 324 S.C. 89, 101, 478 S.E.2d 45, 50
  (1996); BB & T of South Carolina v. Kidwell, 350 S.C. 382, 391, 565
  S.E.2d 316, 320 (Ct. App. 2002); Lee v. Thermal Engineering Corp., 352
  S.C. 81, 88-89, 572 S.E.2d 298, 302 (Ct. App. 2002); Brooklyn Bridge, Inc.
    v. South Carolina Ins. Co., 309 S.C. 141, 145, 420 S.E.2d 511, 513 (Ct.
  App. 1992); Robbins v. First Federal Sav. Bank, 294 S.C. 219, 225, 363
  S.E.2d 418, 421 (Ct. App. 1987); Anderson v. Citizens Bank, 294 S.C.
  387, 398, 365 S.E.2d 26, 32 (Ct. App. 1987) overruled on other grounds by Ward v. Dick Dyer & Associates, Inc., 304
  S.C. 152, 157, 403 S.E.2d 310, 313 (1991); Southern Welding Works, Inc. v. K
    & S Const. Co., 286 S.C. 158, 164, 332 S.E.2d 102, 106 (Ct. App. 1985)
  (citing Ancrum, 29 S.C.L. (2 Speers) 594, 596).
The
  South Carolina Court of Appeals differentiated liquidated and unliquidated
  damages in Beckman Concrete Contractors, Inc. v. United Fire and Cas. Co., 360 S.C. 127, 131-132, 600 S.E.2d 76, 78-79 (Ct. App. 2004):

	In Lewis
  v. Congress of Racial Equality, 275 S.C. 556, 274 S.E.2d 287 (1981), our Supreme
  Court declared:Â  â€œIn liquidated-damages cases, the amount is usually a sum
  certain, or at least the amount is capable of ascertainment by computation.â€Â  
	Id. at 560, 274 S.E.2d at 289.Â  Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary defines liquidated
  damages as â€œ[a]n amount contractually stipulatedâ€ in contrast to unliquidated
  damages which are â€œ[d]amages that â€¦ cannot be determined by a fixed formula, so
  they are left to the discretion of the judge or jury.â€Â  Blackâ€™s Law
    Dictionary 395-97 (7th ed. 1999).Â  Liquidated damages â€œare
  damages the amount of which has been made certain and fixed either by the act
  and agreement of the parties or by operation of law to a sum which cannot be
  changed by the proof.â€Â  22 Am. Jur. 2d Damages Â§ 489 (2003).Â  â€œThey are
  also defined as damages the amount of which has been ascertained by judgment or
  by the specific agreement of the parties or which are susceptible of being made
  certain by mathematical calculation from known factors.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œIn
  general, damages are unliquidated where they are an uncertain quantity,
  depending on no fixed standard, referred to the wise discretion of a jury, and
  can never be made certain except by accord or verdict.â€Â  Id.

In Southern
  Welding Works, Inc., the trial courtâ€™s denial of pre-judgment interest was
  affirmed.Â  286 S.C. at 165, 332 S.E.2d at 106.Â  The South Carolina Court of
  Appeals stated, â€œPrejudgment interest is allowed on liabilities to pay money
  from the time when, either by agreement of the parties or operation of law, the
  payment was demandable, if the sum is certain or capable of being reduced to
  certainty.â€Â  Id.Â  In finding an award of pre-judgment interest was
  inappropriate, the Court explained:

	Southern
  proved the account was actually stated.Â  However, in its answer K & S
  specifically denied the parties ever agreed it was a true account.Â 
  Consequently, the burden was on Southern to prove agreement to the account as
  stated.Â  In the record before us there is no evidence that K & S expressly
  or impliedly agreed there was at any specified time due to Southern the sum of
  money specified in the account.Â  Likewise, we find no evidence that the parties
  agreed to a contract price for the repairs before they were performed.

Id. at 165-166, 332 S.E.2d at 106.Â  Southern Welding
  Works, Inc. illustrates the necessity for an agreement between the parties
  when there is no operation of law to make the sum demandable.Â  Because Southern
  could not prove an agreement with K & S that the sum was actually due, or
  demandable, pre-judgment interest was correctly denied.Â  Id.  
In Wayne Smith
  Const. Co., Inc. v. Woman, Duberstein, & Thompson, 294 S.C. 140, 143,
  363 S.E.2d 115, 117 (Ct. App. 1987), the Court of Appeals affirmed a
  pre-judgment award after finding a sum certain, noting:

	Prejudgment
  interest, however, is allowed on an obligation to pay money â€œfrom the time
  when, either by agreement of the parties or operation of law, the payment is
  demandable, if the sum is certain or capable of being reduced to certainty.â€Â  
	Anderson
    v. Citizens Bank, 365 S.E.2d 26, 32 (S.C. Ct. App. 1987); Robert E. Lee
      & Co. v. Commission of Public Works of City of Greenville, 248 S.C. 92,
  149 S.E.2d 59 (1966).
	Here,
  the sum owed Smith Construction under each contract could be readily
  determined.Â  Under each contract, the partnership was required to pay Smith
  Construction reimbursable costs, plus 10 per cent thereof as a contractorâ€™s fee
  upon the presentation by Smith Construction to the partnership of a waiver of
  liens and a certificate of occupancy.Â  The mere fact that the partnership disagreed
  with Smith Construction regarding the amount of the reimbursable costs did not
  preclude an award of prejudgment interest.Â  Holmes & Son Construction
    Co., Inc. v. Bolo Corp., 22 Ariz. App. 303, 526 P.2d 1258 (1974); see
	Tappan & Noble Harwood, 2 Speers (29 S.C.L.) 536 (1844) (wherein the
  court held in an action involving a contract to build two houses that, while
  the discount claimed by the defendant might reduce the amount due, it did not
  impair the claim for interest on the balance when adjusted by the juryâ€™s
  verdict).

Id. at 146-147, 363 S.E.2d at 119.Â  This case emphasized
  the principle that an amount may be both a sum certain and disputed, and being
  contested does not necessarily preclude a pre-judgment interest award.Â  Id.
Our
  Supreme Court clarified the analysis for pre-judgment interest in Babb v.
    Rothrock, 310 S.C. 350, 426 S.E.2d 789 (1993), when it held:Â  â€œThe proper
  test for determining whether prejudgment interest may be awarded is whether or
  not the measure of recovery, not necessarily the amount of damages, is fixed by
  conditions existing at the time the claim arose.â€Â  Id. at 353, 426
  S.E.2d 791 (citing 47 C.J.S. Interest & Usury Â§ 49 at 124-125
  (1982)); Keane v. Lowcountry Pediatrics, P.A., 372 S.C. 136, 147-148,
  641 S.E.2d 53, 60 (Ct. App. 2007); QHG of Lake City, Inc. v. McCutcheon,
  360 S.C. 196, 205, 600 S.E.2d 105, 109 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Babb personally paid
  an obligation owed by a corporation in which he was a shareholder, without
  notifying Schild, another shareholder.Â  Babb, at 352, 426 S.E.2d 791.Â 
  Babb did not request contribution or notify Schild until he brought suit.Â  Id.Â  The Court determined Babb was entitled to pre-judgment interest, but only from the
  date he filed suit, that being the date the claim arose:Â  â€œBabb did not inform
  Schild that he had personally paid this obligation until he filed this suit
  three years after the payment was made.Â  We hold under these facts that Babb is
  entitled to prejudgment interest only from the date the complaint was filed.â€Â  Id.
More
  recently, in Smith-Hunter Constr. Co., Inc. v. Hopson, 365 S.C. 125,
  128-129, 616 S.E.2d 419, 421 (2005), our Supreme Court upheld an award of
  pre-judgment interest on a breach of contract claim.Â  The Court determined the
  sum demanded was ascertainable and established through the contractorâ€™s
  invoices.Â  Id.Â  The homeowners disputed the amount due, but the Court
  annunciated:Â  â€œThe mere fact that Homeowners disagreed with Builder regarding
  the amounts, which were stated in the invoices, representing completed work did
  not preclude an award of prejudgment interest.â€Â  Id. at 129, 616 S.E.2d
  at 421.Â  The trial court was affirmed â€œbecause the measure of recovery was
  fixed by conditions existing at the time the claim arose.â€Â  Id.
T.W.
  Morton Builders, Inc., v. von Buedingen,
  316 S.C. 388, 450 S.E.2d 87 (Ct. App. 1994) advanced the principle that
  pre-judgment interest is not automatically applied to judgments.Â  Id. at 399, 450 S.E.2d at 93.Â  This Court acknowledged the well-settled rule that
  pre-judgment interest is appropriate where there is a sum certain, where
  parties agree, or where the law provides the payment is demandable.Â  Id.Â  In T.W. Morton Builders, Inc., a home improvement contractor sued to
  foreclose on a mechanicâ€™s lien, and the special master found poor business
  practices on the part of both parties.Â  Id.Â  The Court concluded:

	T.W.
  Mortonâ€™s success in proving the additional amount due for the renovations does
  not automatically translate into entitlement to prejudgment interest on the
  unpaid balance.Â  To establish its right to prejudgment interest, T.W. Morton
  had the burden of establishing a stated account and the partiesâ€™ agreement,
  express or implied, that the account is a true statement due at a specific
  point.Â  The masterâ€™s implicit finding of no stated account is supported by the
  testimony of Dr. von Buedingen, who vigorously disputed the amount due T.W.
  Morton for cost overruns.Â  We accordingly affirm the denial of pre-judgment
  interest.

Id. (internal citations omitted).
In
  the case sub judice, the action arose when the parties failed to
  reach an agreement on the purchase price of Dixie Belleâ€™s interest in Triple
  Crown.Â  Dixie Belleâ€™s damages, however, were unliquidated, not entitling Dixie
  Belle to pre-judgment interest.Â  The claim was unliquidated because:Â  (1) there
  was no agreement between the parties as to a sum certain, (2) it could not be
  reduced to a sum certain by computation or formula, (3) the purchase price was
  not contractually stipulated, (4) it is not reduced to a sum certain by
  operation of law or a controlling statute, and (5) it could only be reduced to
  certainty by a jury determination.Â  Furthermore, the conditions existing at the
  time the claim arose did not fix the measure of recovery.Â  Accordingly, Dixie
  Belleâ€™s claim does not meet the statutory specifications of a sum certain, and Dixie
  Belle is not permitted pre-judgment interest.
CONCLUSION
Dixie
  Belle did not plead for pre-judgment interest, nor did its damages qualify
  under the statute as liquidated or a sum certain.Â  The pre-judgment interest
  awarded to Dixie Belle in the amount of $27,352 on the $100,000 jury verdict
  was in error.Â  Therefore, we
REVERSED.
SHORT and
  WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.
