title: Howard v. Roberson
description: In this civil case, the Appellant presents the following issues: (1) Did the trial court err in effectively granting a new trial nisi additur based on the Thirteenth Juror Doctrine? (2) Did the trial court err in directing a verdict in favor of the Plaintiff on the issue of liability when the evidence did not support a directed verdict against one individual defendant or both defendants jointly? (3) Did the trial court err in granting a new trial against defendant Calvin Roberson only, for damages only, based upon the Thirteenth Juror Doctrine?
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Jodi Howard, Respondent,
				v.
				Calvin
      Roberson and Troy Lawhorn,  Defendants,
				of whom
      Calvin Roberson is Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Lexington County
Â Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4326
Heard December 13, 2007 â€“ Filed December
  20, 2007
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED


	
		
			
				William Bailey Woods, of Lexington, for Appellant.Â 
				
				Gary Walton Popwell, Jr., of Columbia,
  for Respondent.
				Robert A. McKenzie and Gary H. Johnson,
  II, of Columbia,
				Amicus Curiae for Troy Lawhorn.
			
		
	

ANDERSON, J.Â  :Â  This civil action involves Jodi Howardâ€™s claim for damages for
  injuries sustained in an automobile accident against defendants Calvin Roberson
  and Troy Lawhorn.Â  The trial court directed a verdict in Howardâ€™s favor on
  liability.Â  A jury found Roberson liable and awarded Howard damages for medical
  expenses and lost wages only.Â  Howard moved for new trial nisi additur and the trial court granted a new trial on the issue of damages alone against
  Roberson based on the thirteenth juror doctrine.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in
  part, and remand.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On the night of August 23, 2003, Roberson
  and Lawhorn were driving in the same traffic lane on Highway 70.Â  Lawhornâ€™s
  pickup truck was in front of a van driven by an unknown driver, and Roberson
  followed behind the van.Â  Roberson attempted to pass the van in front of his vehicle.Â 
  At the same time, Lawhorn slowed and began to make a left turn onto a public
  road.Â  The vehicles driven by Roberson and Lawhorn collided, injuring Howard, a
  passenger in Lawhornâ€™s truck.Â  Howard initiated this action against Roberson
  and Lawhorn to recover damages for his injuries.Â   
At the close of the defendantsâ€™ case, Howard moved for a directed
  verdict on the issue of negligence against Roberson for violation of section
  56-5-1880 of the South Carolina Code (2006).Â  Section 56-5-1880(a)(2) prohibits
  vehicles from driving on the left side of a roadway â€œ[w]hen approaching within
  one hundred feet of or traversing any intersection.â€Â  The trial court granted Howardâ€™s
  motion for directed verdict but not against Roberson alone.Â  Instead, the trial
  court granted the motion finding, â€œThere is evidence of negligence on both or
  one of the defendants.â€Â  The trial court later instructed the jury, â€œ[Y]ou may
  find against the Defendant, Mr. Roberson, or you may find against the
  Defendant, Mr. Lawhorn, or you can find against both of them.Â  You can find
  against one of the two or you can find against both.â€  
During
  deliberation, the jury asked the trial court if they could apportion seventy-five
  percent of the fault to Roberson and twenty-five percent to Lawhorn.Â  The trial
  court explained the jury could not assign fault in that manner.Â  Neither party
  raised this issue on appeal.Â  The
  jury found only Roberson negligent and awarded Howard $7,672.47 in actual damages
  for medical expenses and lost wages. Â The award did not reflect inclusion of
  pain and suffering.Â  Howard moved for a new trial nisi additur, stating
  the jury apparently ignored the law as it related to pain and suffering.Â  The
  trial court took the matter under advisement and, in a form order, granted
  Howard a new trial solely on the issue of damages based on the thirteenth juror
  doctrine.Â  In its subsequent written order the trial court ruled the juryâ€™s
  findings regarding pain and suffering were â€œcontrary to the fair preponderance
  of the evidence [and] . . . [t]he Plaintiff suffered obvious injuries which
  obviously had to be painful.â€Â   
ISSUES

	
		
			1. 
			
			Did the trial court err in
  directing a verdict in Howardâ€™s favor on the issue
  of liability?
 
		
		
			2.
			Did the trial court err in 
			granting Howard a new trial on damages based
  on the thirteenth juror doctrine?
		
	

STANDARD OF REVIEW
When reviewing a trial
  courtâ€™s ruling on a directed verdict, this court will reverse if no evidence
  supports the trial courtâ€™s decision or the ruling is controlled by an error of
  law.Â  Law v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Corr., 368 S.C. 424, 434-35, 629 S.E.2d 642,
  648 (2006); McMillan v. Oconee Memâ€™l Hosp., Inc., 367 S.C. 559, 564, 626
  S.E.2d 884, 886 (2006).Â  The appellate court must determine whether a verdict
  for the party opposing the motion would be reasonably possible under the facts
  as liberally construed in his or her favor.Â  Pye v. Estate of Fox, 369
  S.C. 555, 564, 633 S.E.2d 505, 509 (2006); Ericson v. Jones St. Publishers,
    L.L.C., 368 S.C. 444, 463, 629 S.E.2d 653, 663 (2006).Â  If the evidence as
  a whole is susceptible to more than one reasonable inference, a jury issue is
  created and the motion should be denied.Â  Proctor v. Depâ€™t of Health and
    Envtl. Control, 368 S.C. 279, 292, 628 S.E.2d 496, 503 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  A
  motion for directed verdict goes to the entire case and may be granted only
  when the evidence raises no issue for the jury as to liability.Â  The
    Huffines Co., LLC v. Lockhart, 365 S.C. 178, 187, 617 S.E.2d 125, 129 (Ct.
  App. 2005).Â  When considering directed verdict motions, neither the trial court
  nor the appellate court has authority to decide credibility issues or to
  resolve conflicts in the testimony or evidence.Â  Wright v. Craft, 372
  S.C. 1, 19, 640 S.E.2d 486, 496 (Ct. App. 2006) (citing Erickson, 368
  S.C. at 463, 629 S.E.2d at 663).  
â€œThe
  grant or denial of new trial motions rests within the discretion of the trial
  judge and his decision will not be disturbed on appeal unless his findings are
  wholly unsupported by the evidence or the conclusions reached are controlled by
  error of law.â€ Â Chapman v. Upstate RV & Marine, 364 S.C. 82, 88-89
  610 S.E.2d 852, 856 (Ct. App. 2005) (citing Vinson v. Hartley, 324 S.C.
  389, 405, 477 S.E.2d 715, 723 (Ct. App. 1996); Trivelas v. S.C. Depâ€™t of
    Transp., 357 S.C. 545, 553, 593 S.E.2d 504, 508 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  An
  appellate court may only reverse a trial courtâ€™s decision regarding a new trial nisi if the trial court abused its discretion in deciding a motion for
  new trial nisi additur to the extent an error of law results.Â  Green
    v. Fritz, 356 S.C. 566, 570, 590 S.E.2d 39, 41 (Ct. App. 2003).Â   
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Directed Verdict Motion
Roberson argues the
  trial court erred in granting Howard a directed verdict motion.Â  Specifically,
  Roberson contends because Howard
  made a motion for a directed verdict against Roberson alone, the trial court
  erred in granting the motion holding either Roberson or Lawhorn or both drivers
  negligent.Â  We disagree.Â   
When evidence
  presented at trial yields only one conclusion concerning liability, a trial
  court may properly grant a motion for directed verdict.Â  See Ecclesiastes
    Prod. Ministries v. Outparcel Assocs., LLC, 374 S.C. 483, 490, 649 S.E.2d
  494, 497 (Ct. App. 2007) (citing Carolina Home Builders, Inc. v. Armstrong
    Furnace Co., 259 S.C. 346, 358, 191 S.E.2d 774, 779 (1972)). Â See also Swinton Creek Nursery v. Edisto Farm Credit, ACA, 334 S.C. 469, 476-77,
  514 S.E.2d 126, 130 (1999) (â€œWhen the evidence yields only one inference, a
  directed verdict in favor of the moving party is proper.â€). Â In considering a
  motion for directed verdict, the trial court must view the evidence and
  inferences that can be drawn from it in the light most favorable to the non-moving
  party.Â  Doe v. ATC, Inc., 367 S.C. 199, 204, 624 S.E.2d 447, 449 (Ct. App.
  2005); (citing Sabb v. S.C. State Univ., 350 S.C. 416, 427, 567 S.E.2d
  231, 236 (2002)).Â  So long as no more than one inference is created from the
  evidence presented, a jury issue is not created, and the trial court is proper
  in directing a verdict.Â  Henson v. Intâ€™l Paper Co., 358 S.C. 133, 147, 594
  S.E.2d 499, 506 (Ct. App. 2004) (holding where the evidence is susceptible of
  more than one reasonable inference, a jury issue is created and the court may
  not grant a directed verdict).Â Â Â   
In the case sub judice, Roberson and Lawhorn each owed a duty to other drivers and
  passengers like Howard when operating their respective vehicles.Â  Pursuant to section
  56-5-2150 of the South Carolina Code (2006), Lawhorn had a duty to turn his
  vehicle safely and use the appropriate turn signal when making a left turn onto
  a roadway.Â  Specifically, section 56-5-2150(a) provides, â€œNo person shall turn
  a vehicle or move right or left upon a roadway unless and until such movement
  can be made with reasonable safety nor without giving an appropriate signal as
  provided for in this section.â€Â  Additionally, section 56-5-2150(b) mandates, â€œA
  signal of intention to turn or move right or left when required shall be given
  continuously during not less than the last one hundred feet traveled by the
  vehicle before turning.â€ Â Accordingly, the law compelled Lawhorn to signal and
  turn safely.Â Â   
Likewise,
  Roberson owed a duty pursuant to section 56-5-1880 of the South Carolina Code (2006) not to pass other vehicles within one hundred feet of
  an intersection.Â  The trial court defined â€œintersectionâ€ as â€œ[t]he junction of
  an unimproved road publicly maintained with a paved highway.â€Â  See Carma
    v. Swindler, 228 S.C. 550, 557, 91 S.E.2d 254, 258 (1956); see also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-490 (2006).Â  Furthermore, â€œThe driver of a vehicle
  overtaking another vehicle proceeding in the same direction shall pass to the
  left thereof at a safe distance and shall not again drive to the right side of
  the roadway until safely clear of the overtaken vehicle.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-1840(1)
  (2006).Â  South Carolina jurisprudence required Roberson to abide by these
  statutes as he passed the van on the night of the accident. Â Finally, both Roberson
  and Lawhorn were required to drive their automobiles at a safe and reasonable
  speed under the conditions existing at the time of the accident.Â  S.C. Code Ann.
  Â§ 56-5-1520 (2006).Â  Whether Lawhorn and Roberson complied with these laws
  created a question for the jury.
In
  granting Howardâ€™s motion for a directed verdict, the trial court found either Roberson,
  or Lawhorn, or both, breached at least one duty on the night of the accident.Â  The
  effect of the courtâ€™s decision left the issue of who was liable open for determination
  by the trier of fact.Â  The juryâ€™s task was to decide which driver, if not both,
  was at fault and to calculate damages.  
The trial
  court properly directed a verdict for Howard on the issue of liability.Â  The
  evidence presented at trial yielded only one conclusionâ€”that the negligence of
  at least one driver, if not both, resulted in the accident causing Howardâ€™s
  injuries.Â  The trial court did not err in granting a directed verdict on the
  issue of liability.Â   
II.Â  Â New Trial on Issue of Damages  
A.Â 
  Thirteenth Juror DoctrineÂ  
Roberson
  contends the trial court erred in granting a new trial solely on the issue of
  damages pursuant to the thirteenth juror doctrine.Â  We agree.Â   
The following
  excerpt from Vinson v. Hartley, 324 S.C. 389, 477 S.E.2d 715 (Ct. App.
  1996) outlines South Carolina jurisprudential history concerning the thirteenth
  juror doctrine:  

	The
  seminal case stating the â€œthirteenth jurorâ€ doctrine is Worrell v. South
    Carolina Power Co., 186 S.C. 306, 195 S.E. 638 (1938).Â  Worrell states:
	Nor does
  it follow that because under the law the trial judge is compelled to submit the
  issues to the jury, he cannot grant a new trial absolute. Â As has often been
  said, the trial judge is the thirteenth juror, possessing the veto power to the
  Nth degree, and, it must be presumed, recognizes and appreciates his
  responsibility, and exercises the discretion vested in him with fairness and
  impartiality.Â  Worrell, 186 S.C. at 313-14, 195 S.E. at 641.
	A review of the â€œthirteenth jurorâ€ doctrine
  was undertaken by the appellate entity in Folkens v. Hunt, 300 S.C. 251,
  387 S.E.2d 265 (1990):
	
		This
  Court has had an opportunity to reconsider the thirteenth juror doctrine on
  several occasions. Â Each time we have refused to abolish the doctrine. Â We have
  also refused to require trial judges to explain the reasons for the ruling. Â The
  thirteenth juror doctrine is a vehicle by which the trial court may grant a new
  trial absolute when he finds that the evidence does not justify the verdict. Â This
  ruling has also been termed granting a new trial upon the facts. Â The effect is
  the same as if the jury failed to reach a verdict. Â The judge as the thirteenth
  juror â€œhangsâ€ the jury. Â When a jury fails to reach a verdict, a new trial is
  ordered. Â Neither judge nor the jury is required to give reasons for this
  outcome. Â Similarly, because the result of the â€œthirteenth jurorâ€ vote by the
  judge is a new trial rather than an adjustment to the verdict, no purpose would
  be served by requiring the trial judge to make factual findings.
		A trial
  judgeâ€™s order granting or denying a new trial upon the facts will not be
  disturbed unless his decision is wholly unsupported by the evidence, or the
  conclusion reached was controlled by an error of law. Â When an order granting a
  new trial is before this Court, our review is limited to the consideration of
  whether evidence exists to support the trial courtâ€™s order. 
	
	Folkens, 300 S.C. at 254-55, 387 S.E.2d at 267 (citations
  omitted).
	The
  trial judge, sitting as the thirteenth juror charged with the duty of seeing
  that justice is done, has the authority to grant new trials when he is
  convinced that a new trial is necessitated on the basis of the facts in the
  case. Â Graham v. Whitaker, 282 S.C. 393, 321 S.E.2d 40 (1984). Â Traditionally,
  in South Carolina, circuit court judges have the authority to grant a new trial
  upon the judgeâ€™s finding that justice has not prevailed. Â Todd v. Owen
    Indus. Prods., Inc., 315 S.C. 34, 431 S.E.2d 596 (Ct. App. 1993). Â Similarly,
  the judge may grant a new trial if the verdict is inconsistent and reflects the
  juryâ€™s confusion. Â Johnson v. Parker, 279 S.C. 132, 303 S.E.2d 95
  (1983). Â See also Johnson v. Hoechst Celanese Corp., 317 S.C.
  415, 453 S.E.2d 908 (Ct. App. 1995) (under â€œthirteenth juror doctrine,â€ trial
  court may grant new trial if judge believes verdict is unsupported by evidence
  and, similarly, new trial may be granted if verdict is inconsistent and
  reflects juryâ€™s confusion). Â 

324 S.C. at 402, 477 S.E.2d
  at 702.
In Norton
  v. North S. Ry Co., 350 S.C. 473, 478, 567 S.E.2d 851, 854 (2002), the South
  Carolina Supreme Court explained, â€œthe thirteenth juror doctrine is so named because
  it entitles a trial court to sit, in essence, as the thirteenth juror when [it]
  finds â€˜the evidence does not justify the verdict,â€™ and then to grant a new
  trial based solely â€˜upon the facts.â€™â€ (citing Folkens v. Hunt, 300 S.C.
  251, 387 S.E.2d 265 (1990)).Â  The supreme court further held, â€œ[T]he result of
  the â€˜thirteenth jurorâ€™ vote by the judge is a new trial rather than an
  adjustment to the verdict . . . .â€Â  Norton, 350 S.C. at 478, 567 S.E.2d
  at 854.Â  In essence, the judge, as the thirteenth juror, can hang the jury and
  start the trial anew.Â   
Our
  supreme court recently affirmed a court of appealsâ€™ decision upholding the grant
  of a new trial absolute under the thirteenth juror doctrine.Â  Trivelas v. S.C.
    Depâ€™t of Transp., 357 S.C. 545, 551-52, 593 S.E.2d 504, 508 (2004).Â  The
  supreme court reasoned the grant was warranted because justice was not served
  by the juryâ€™s verdict, and the evidence did not justify the result.Â  Id. at 552, 593 S.E.2d at 508.Â  The Trivelas court held granting a new trial
  under the thirteenth juror doctrine has the same effect as if the jury failed
  to reach a verdict, and the trial court is not required to give reasons for
  granting a new trial.Â  Id. at 553, 593 S.E.2d at 508 (citing Folkens,
  300 S.C. at 254, 387 S.E.2d at 267).Â   
â€œThe
  â€˜thirteenth jurorâ€™ doctrine is not used when the trial judge has found the
  verdict was inadequate or unduly liberal and, therefore, is not a vehicle to
  grant a new trial nisi additur.â€Â  Bailey v. Peacock, 318
  S.C. 13, 14-15, 455 S.E.2d 690, 692 (1995); see also Pinckney
    v. Winn-Dixie Stores, Inc., 311 S.C. 1, 4-5, 426 S.E.2d 327, 329 (Ct. App.
  1992).Â   
B.Â 
  New Trial Absolute and New Trial Nisi Additur
A
  trial court may grant a new trial absolute on the ground that the verdict is
  excessive or inadequate. Â Stevens v. Allen, 336 S.C. 439, 447, 520
  S.E.2d 625, 629 (Ct. App. 1999) affâ€™d by 342 S.C. 47, 536 S.E.2d 663
  (2000) (citing Vinson v. Hartley, 324 S.C. 389, 404, 477 S.E.2d 715, 723
  (Ct. App. 1996)).Â  Additionally, a new trial is warranted if the verdict is
  inconsistent. Â See Rush v. Blanchard, 310 S.C. 375, 426 S.E.2d
  802 (1993). Â The juryâ€™s determination of damages, however, is entitled to
  substantial deference. Â Id. Â The trial judge must grant a new trial
  absolute if the amount of the verdict is grossly inadequate or excessive so as
  to shock the conscience of the court and clearly indicates the figure reached
  was the result of passion, caprice, prejudice, partiality, corruption or some
  other improper motives. Â See Cock-n-Bull Steak House, Inc. v.
    Generali Ins. Co., 321 S.C. 1, 466 S.E.2d 727 (1996); McCourt by
      and Through McCourt v. Abernathy, 318 S.C. 301, 457 S.E.2d 603 (1995); Allstate
        Ins. Co. v. Durham, 314 S.C. 529, 431 S.E.2d 557 (1993). Â The failure of
  the trial judge to grant a new trial absolute in this situation amounts to an
  abuse of discretion and on appeal this court will grant a new trial absolute.Â  Stevens,
  336 S.C. at 452, 520 S.E.2d at 631.Â  Â 
Alternatively,
  the trial court may grant a new trial nisi additur or remittitur when it finds the verdict is merely inadequate or excessive. Â Id. â€œ[T]he
  trial judge must distinguish between awards that are merely unduly liberal or
  conservative and awards that are actuated by passion, caprice or prejudice.â€Â  Id. (citing Allstate Ins. Co., 314 S.C. at 530, 431 S.E.2d at 558).Â  A new
  trial nisi is one in which a new trial will be granted unless the party
  opposing it complies with conditions set by the court. Â Elliott v. Black River Elec. Coop., 233 S.C. 233, 104 S.E.2d 357, 372 (1958).Â  â€œA motion for a new
  trial nisi because of excessiveness of the verdict contemplates not the
  striking down of the verdict in toto, but remission of part of it and the
  granting of a new trial in default thereof.â€Â  Id.Â  The trial court essentially
  gives the party against whom damages are assessed the option, by way of additur or remittitur, of avoiding a new trial.
The
  granting of a motion for new trial nisi additur or remittitur rests within the sound discretion of the trial court, but substantial deference
  must be afforded to the juryâ€™s determination of damages.Â  Green v. Fritz,
  356 S.C. 566, 570, 590 S.E.2d 39, 41 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Compelling reasons must be given to justify invading
  the juryâ€™s province in this manner. Â Chapman v. Upstate RV & Marine,
  364 S.C. 82, 89, 610 S.E.2d 852, 856 (Ct. App. 2005) (citing Pelican Bldg.
    Ctrs. v. Dutton, 311 S.C. 56, 61, 427 S.E.2d 673, 676 (1993)).Â   
In
  summary, the court of appeals in Proctor v. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl.
    Control, offers an explanation of this process in gargantuan detail:

	A new
  trial nisi is one in which a new trial will be granted unless the party
  opposing it complies with a condition set by the court.Â  The grant or denial of
  new trial motions rests within the discretion of the trial judge, and his
  decision will not be disturbed on appeal unless his findings are wholly
  unsupported by the evidence or the conclusions reached are controlled by error
  of law.Â  The trial court alone has the power to grant a new trial nisi when he finds the amount of the verdict to be merely inadequate or excessive.Â 
  However, compelling reasons must be given to justify invading the juryâ€™s
  province by granting a new trial nisi [additur or] remittitur.Â 
  The consideration for a motion for a new trial nisi [additur or]remittitur
  requires the trial judge to consider the adequacy of the verdict in light of
  the evidence presented.Â  Great deference is given to the trial judge who heard
  the evidence and is more familiar with the evidentiary atmosphere at trial, and
  who thus possesses a better-informed view of the damages than this Court.Â  When
  considering a motion for a new trial based on the inadequacy or excessiveness
  of the juryâ€™s verdict, the trial court must distinguish between awards that are
  merely unduly liberal or conservative and awards that are actuated by passion,
  caprice, or prejudice.Â  If the amount of the verdict is grossly inadequate or
  excessive so as to be the result of passion, caprice, prejudice, or some other
  influence outside the evidence, the trial judge must grant a new trial
  absolute.

368 S.C. 279, 319-21, 628
  S.E.2d 496, 518 (Ct. App. 2006) (internal citations and quotation marks
  omitted).Â  Â Â 
C.Â 
  A Procedural Conundrum
Â We
  address the equivocality extant in this record.Â  The only motion posited by
  Howard was a motion for a new trial nisi additur.Â  The record
  reveals this with certitude: Â 

	On
  behalf of the Plaintiff, I would make a motion for a new trial nisi additur.Â 
  Obviously the jury gave a verdict for the exact amount of the medical expenses,
  chiropractic expenses, and wage loss.Â  They obviously ignored your charge as to
  pain and suffering.Â  If all the medical expenses and wage loss were justified,
  then how can the pain and suffering which necessitated the medical expenses not
  be compensable?Â  They ignored the law as it relates to pain and suffering
  obviously.

The
  trial court failed to rule on Howardâ€™s motion for a new trial nisi additur.Â 
  The circuit judge granted a new trial on damages alone based on the thirteenth
  juror doctrine.Â   
Our precedent
  firmly establishes the grant of a new trial based on the thirteenth juror
  doctrine grants a new trial in toto.Â  The thirteenth juror doctrine is not the
  proper vehicle for ordering a new trial on a singular issue such as damages.Â  Therefore,
  the trial court erred in granting a new trial solely on damages based on the
  thirteenth juror doctrine.Â   
Though
  Howard was entitled to a directed verdict in his favor on the issue of
  liability, the directed verdict did not specifically hold Roberson liable to
  Howard.Â  Moreover, Roberson did not appeal the juryâ€™s finding that Lawhorn was
  not liable and Lawhorn was not made a party to this appeal.Â  The determination
  that Lawhorn was not liable is now the law of the case.Â  First Union Natâ€™l
    Bank of S.C. v. Soden, 333 S.C. 554, 566, 511 S.E.2d 372, 378 (Ct. App. 1998)
  (â€œThe unchallenged ruling, right or wrong, is the law of the case and requires
  affirmance.â€)  
Consequently, we
  remand this case back to the trial court to rule on Howardâ€™s new trial nisi additur motion.Â  Roberson must comply with the trial courtâ€™s order
  regarding additur to avoid a new trial as the sole defendant.
CONCLUSION
The trial
  court properly granted Howardâ€™s motion for directed verdict.Â  However, the trial
  court erred by granting a new trial on the issue of damages alone against
  Roberson under the thirteenth juror doctrine.Â  Procedurally, the trial court
  cannot use the doctrine as a vehicle to grant a plaintiff a new trial on the
  issue of damages alone.Â  Instead, the trial court should have ruled on Howardâ€™s
  motion for new trial nisi additur, and in its discretion, increased
  damages for pain and suffering.Â  At that juncture, the opposing party must be
  given the option to comply with the additur or be granted a new trial
  absolute.Â  If the option utilized by the opposing party in contradistinction to
  the nisi additur is a new trial absolute, then and in that event only,
  the new trial absolute is against Roberson because Lawhorn has been eliminated
  from this case as a matter of law.Â  Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s order is
 
AFFIRMED IN
  PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.
SHORT and
  WILLIAMS, JJ. concur.

description: James Odom appeals the circuit courtâ€™s determination that police had probable cause to seize him in a traffic stop.  He further argues that because the stop was illegal, the marijuana seized during the stop should have been suppressed.  We affirm.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				James Odom, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Beaufort County
Perry M. Buckner, III, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4327
Heard November 7, 2007 â€“ Filed December
  20, 2007Â Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Jared S. Newman, of Beaufort, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott,
  Assistant Attorney General Shawn L. Reeves, all of Columbia; and Solicitor I.
  McDuffie Stone, III, of Beaufort, for Respondent.
			
		
	

HEARN, C.J.:Â  James
  Odom appeals the circuit courtâ€™s determination that police had probable cause
  to seize him in a traffic stop.Â  He further argues that because the stop was
  illegal, the marijuana seized during the stop should have been suppressed.Â  We
  affirm.
FACTS
On September 4, 2002, Odom was pulled over
  by two officers who witnessed Odom driving a vehicle without wearing a
  seatbelt.Â  Officer Carter, one of the two officers who witnessed the violation,
  approached Odomâ€™s vehicle to explain to him why he had been pulled over.Â  As
  Carter drew near to Odomâ€™s vehicle, he smelled a strong odor of marijuana and recognized
  a Swisher-Sweet cigar[1] on the dashboard.Â  Carter asked Odom if he had smoked marijuana, and Odom admitted
  he had done so earlier that same morning.Â  In addition, Carter noticed a
  security guard belt with a gun holster in the rear passenger seat, although the
  holster was empty at the time.Â  
Believing that a weapon could be present, Carter asked Odom to
  exit the vehicle and thereafter conducted a Terry frisk.[2] Â Carter testified he felt a bundle of
  leafy material in the breast pocket of Odomâ€™s jacket, which he immediately
  recognized as marijuana because of the extensive training he had received on
  the Drug Interdicton Force from the United States Department of Homeland
  Security.Â  After finding the drugs, Carter placed Odom under arrest; continued
  his search; and located a second larger bag, and two smaller bags of marijuana,
  totaling 4.361 ounces.Â  
Odom was indicted for possession of marijuana with the intent to
  distribute.Â  At the start of the trial, Odomâ€™s counsel moved to suppress the
  marijuana as a product of an illegal search and seizure.Â  The court overruled
  this motion.Â  Following presentation of the stateâ€™s case, the court, sitting
  non-jury, found Odom guilty and sentenced him to five yearsâ€™ confinement.Â  This
  appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The admission of
  evidence is within the discretion of the trial court and will not be reversed
  absent an abuse of discretion. Â State v. Gaster, 349 S.C. 545, 557, 564
  S.E.2d 87, 93 (2002). Â An abuse of discretion occurs when the conclusions of
  the trial court either lack evidentiary support or are controlled by an error
  of law. Â State v. McDonald, 343 S.C. 319, 325, 540 S.E.2d 464, 467
  (2000).
In criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review
  errors of law only.Â  State v. Butler, 353 S.C. 383, 388, 577 S.E.2d 498,
  500 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  We are bound by the trial courtâ€™s factual findings
  unless they are clearly erroneous.Â  Id. at 388, 577 S.E.2d at 500-01.Â 
  This same standard of review applies to preliminary factual findings in
  determining the admissibility of certain evidence in criminal cases.Â  State
    v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5-6, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001).Â  Our review in
  Fourth Amendment search and seizure cases is limited to determining whether any
  evidence supports the trial courtâ€™s finding.Â  State v. Bowman, 366 S.C.
  485, 501, 623 S.E.2d 378, 386 (2005).Â  An appellate court will reverse
  only when there is clear error.Â  Id. 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Existence of Probable
  Cause for Initial Seizure
Odom first asserts
  the circuit court erred in finding the officers had probable cause to seize him
  based on their limited opportunity to view whether he was wearing his seatbelt,
  the distance between the vehicles, and the dark tint of Odomâ€™s windows.Â  We
  disagree.
Section 56-5-6520 of
  the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006) requires drivers or occupants to wear a
  complying, fastened safety belt when the motor vehicle in which they are riding
  is being operated on the public streets and highways of South Carolina.Â  A law
  enforcement officer may pull over or stop a vehicle when the officer has probable
  cause of a seatbelt violation based on a clear and unobstructed view of someone
  within the vehicle who is not wearing a seatbelt.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-6540
  (Supp. 2006).Â  Odomâ€™s counsel used a series of photos during his
  cross-examination of the arresting officers in order to illustrate it would
  have been impossible for the officers to recognize a seatbelt violation, during
  similar circumstances.Â  However, both Officer Carter and his fellow patrolman
  Officer Dansky, testified to clearly seeing Odom across an intersection from
  where they were parked, operating a motor vehicle without wearing a safety
  belt.Â  Because there is testimony in the record upon which the circuit court
  could base its judgment, we cannot say the court abused its discretion in finding
  the officers had probable cause to seize Odom due to his seatbelt violation.Â 
See Bowman, 366 S.C. at 501, 623 S.E.2d at 386.
II. Legality of Detainment
  and Patdown
Odom next asserts
  the circuit court erred in admitting evidence of marijuana found on him during
  the seizure.Â  Specifically, Odom contends the search violated the safety belt
  legislation enacted by our legislature.Â  We disagree.
Section
  56-5-6540(D) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006) provides:Â  â€œA vehicle,
  driver, or occupant in a vehicle must not be searched, nor may consent to
  search be requested by a law enforcement officer, solely because of a violation
  of this article.â€Â  Odom argues the alleged seatbelt violation was the only
  cause for the subsequent search.Â  We find this argument is misguided.Â  As
  discussed above, a seatbelt violation can be the sole basis for a police
  officer to pull over a vehicle.Â  Section 56-5-6540(D) emphasizes this initial
  seizure cannot be extended to a subsequent search without additional suspicion
  rising to the level of probable cause.Â  In this case, Officer Carter smelled a
  strong odor of marijuana as he approached Odomâ€™s car and noticed a common indicium of paraphernalia, a Swisher-Sweet cigar, on the dashboard.Â 
  Additionally, Odom admitted to smoking marijuana earlier in the day, and
  Officer Carter observed an empty gun holster in the back seat.Â  Having cause to
  fear for his own safety and reasonable suspicion of the existence of drugs,
  Officer Carter asked Odom to exit the vehicle and conducted a Terry search.Â  

In Terry,
  the United States Supreme Court announced that police may briefly detain and
  conduct a reasonable search for weapons where the officer has reason to believe
  the person is armed.Â  Terry, 392 U.S. 1, 27 (1968).Â  Applying this concept,
  the Supreme Court has also held once a vehicle has been lawfully detained for a
  traffic violation, police officers may order the driver out of the vehicle and
  conduct a search for weapons where the officer believes the person is armed and
  dangerous.Â  Pennsylvania v. Mimms, 434 U.S. 106, 111-12 (1977).Â  â€œThe
  officer need not be absolutely certain that the individual is armed; the issue
  is whether a reasonably prudent man in the circumstances would be warranted in
  the belief that his safety or that of others was in danger.â€Â  Terry at
  27.Â  The existence of the evidence described above gave Carter the reasonable
  suspicion necessary to perform a patdown for weapons; therefore, Officer Carterâ€™s
  search was not solely based on Odomâ€™s seatbelt violation.[3]Â Â  
III. â€œPlain-Feel Doctrineâ€
Finally, Odom
  contends the circuit court erred in admitting the marijuana because the video in
  the police squad car allegedly shows a violation of the â€œplain-feelâ€ rule
  annunciated in Minnesota v. Dickerson, 508 U.S. 366 (1993). Â Odom argues
  even if the initial traffic stop and Carterâ€™s decision to patdown Odom were
  valid, the patdown exceeded the bounds established under Terry and
  confirmed in Dickerson.Â  We disagree.
Before the start of
  the trial, Odomâ€™s counsel made a motion to suppress the evidence gained from
  the seizure and subsequent search.Â  In support of this motion, Odom played the
  in-car video of Officer Carterâ€™s stop, which Odom argues provides evidence
  Carterâ€™s frisk exceeded constitutional bounds.Â  In Dickerson, the
  Supreme Court confronted for the first time the issue of a police officer who conducted
  a patdown search pursuant to Terry which did not yield a weapon; however,
  the officer recognized and seized nonthreatening contraband detected during the
  patdown.Â  Dickerson at 369, 373.Â  Where the seizure remains within the
  bounds of Terry, the Court reasoned:

	If
  a police officer lawfully pats down a suspectâ€™s outer clothing and feels an
  object whose contour or mass makes its identity immediately apparent, there has
  been no invasion of the suspectâ€™s privacy beyond that already authorized by the
  officerâ€™s search for weapons; if the object is contraband, its warrantless
  seizure would be justified by the
  same practical considerations that inhere in the plain-view context.

Id. at 375-76.Â  However, the Court in Dickerson found the officer did not immediately recognize the incriminating character of
  the object in the suspectâ€™s pocket.Â  Instead, it only became apparent after
  â€œsqueezing, sliding and otherwise manipulating the contents of the defendantâ€™s
  pocket â€“ a pocket which the officer already knew contained no weapon.â€Â  Id. at 378.
We find the case
  before us is distinguishable from Dickerson, and more closely aligned
  with our courtâ€™s decision in State v. Smith, 329 S.C. 550, 495 S.E.2d
  798 (Ct. App. 1998) cert. denied.Â  In Smith, police pulled
  a suspect over for speeding and, pursuant to a reasonable suspicion, asked the
  suspect to exit the vehicle and thereafter conducted a Terry search.Â 
  The officer conducting the search testified he immediately recognized a bulge
  in one of the suspectâ€™s pockets as a narcotic despite admitting he â€œsqueezed the
  outside of [suspectâ€™s] jacketâ€ and â€œsqueezed around the package.â€Â  Smith at 560, 495 S.E.2d at 803.Â  This court distinguished 
Dickerson,
  explaining, â€œ[a]lthough there is testimony in the record [the police officer]
  squeezed the outside of [suspectâ€™s] jacket, we do not find this sufficient to
  invalidate the seizure under Dickerson.â€Â  Id.Â  Â 
As in Smith,
  during Odomâ€™s pre-trial suppression hearing, Carter testified he recognized immediately the bundle of
  leafy material in the breast pocket of Odomâ€™s jacket as marijuana, testifying:Â 
  â€œOnce [Odom] steeped [sic] out of the vehicle I smelled a strong odor of
  marijuana coming from his body, started the search and felt the large bundle in
  his breast pocket then I knew what it was, it was a bag of marijuana.â€Â 
  Accordingly, we find the circuit court did not abuse its discretion in finding
  Carterâ€™s search stayed within the bounds of Terry, as clarified in Smith,
  and allowing the fruits of that search to be admitted into evidence.
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, we hold the circuit court did not err: (1) in
  finding probable cause to initially seize Odom due to a seatbelt violation; (2)
  in admitting the marijuana seized during the search; or (3) in
  determining the officerâ€™s patdown search did not extend past the â€œplain-feelâ€
  rule allowed under Terry.Â  The decision of the circuit court is
  accordingly
AFFIRMED.
KITTREDGE, J., and THOMAS, J., concur.

[1] Carter testified a Swisher-Sweet cigar is commonly
  known as a â€œblunt,â€ which refers to a cigar that has been hollowed and refilled
  with marijuana. The term â€œbluntâ€ was originally derived from the preferred
  brand of cigars for this operation, Phillies Blunts, but can refer to any brand
  of store-bought cigars.Â  See Urban Dictionary, available at http://www.urbandictionary.com.
[2] Terry
